Keith Boudreau, 42, of Quincy was pronounced dead on Friday morning following the March 23 attack where he was knocked to the ground and had his head stomped on while at Home Ice Sports Bar. Paul Fahey, 43, allegedly beat him for just staring in his direction, according to court documents. He was taken to hospital with life-threatening injuries following the attack and was removed from life support on Monday. On Wednesday, Fahey was arraigned on assault and battery charges, and pleaded not guilty. The Norfolk District Attorney's office said Friday that they are seeking to arraign Fahey again and charge him with murder on Monday morning.
Peter Schweizer's new book, Clinton Cash, is due to be published on May 5th by HarperCollins. It claims there is a clear trend of money flowing into the controversial Clinton Foundation and rewards emerging for donors - in forms such as free trade agreements and development projects. Clinton allies have characterized the book as simply the latest in a series of 'absurd conspiracy theories' designed to derail Clinton's 2016 campaign.
Latika Bourke had no interest about looking into her origins until she watched the movie Slumdog Millionaire and realised how profoundly different her life would have been if her new parents didn't take her in their arms. The film was nothing short of life-changing for Latika and led her to a fulfilling spiritual journey back to where it all began in an orphanage in the slums of India - the country she instantly fell in love with and has become her second home.
An intense low-pressure system known as an East Coast Low is battering the NSW coast. The stormy weather system, formed in the Tasman Sea, hasn't hit NSW this strong since 2007 and is expected to be one of the longest lasting ever. East Coast Lows are particularly common in June and tend to be more frequent in autumn and winter. They are characterised by gales or storm force winds that can damage buildings, fell trees and powerlines, cause powerful surf and, in some cases, run ships aground.
Xiao Ying, 17, dumped her newborn child in a factory toilet after giving birth. She then went back to work on a shoe production line in Wenzhou City, China. The baby boy was found in the female toilets of a shoe factory by a cleaner. Authorities at the factory found the mother back working on the production line. She denied giving birth, but came clean when managers saw blood on her shoes.
Flow VR provides passengers with a virtual image of the horizon that mimics the movements of the aircraft. This can help to combat the conflict between the information coming from a person's eyes and their sense of balance in the inner ear, which can lead to travel sickness. It can also present travellers with high quality images of their destination that replicate the time of day to help them acclimatise to their new time zone.
Patrick Randall was 16 in May 1990 when he held a knife to Gregory Smart's throat as his friend Billy Flynn, shot him in the head. Flynn was Pamela Smart's then-16-year-old lover and shot her husband dead at her request. Randall and Flynn pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and after plea bargains eventually got sentences of 28 years to life.

Video shows how Angelo West, 41, immediately jumps out of the car and shoots Officer John Moynihan under the eye at close range after the policeman opens the driver-side door. West then fires at the other officers as he runs across the busy street. The video, captured from the surveillance camera of a nearby store, shows the beginning of the shootout that led to the fatal shots that killed West.
Robin Ellis shot to fame in the Seventies as the original dashing hero Ross Poldark. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes by chance in 1999, aged 58, after a friend was diagnosed. In type 2, the body's cells fail to react to insulin, causing blood sugar levels to soar. This can lead to blindness, kidney damage, heart disease and circulation problems.

The town has gone into overdrive for the celebrations, lining the streets with bunting and creating special-themed produce in many of the stories.

Psychologists from Goldsmiths University of London, and Ohio State University in the US studied more than 13,000 twins aged nine to 16 from six countries, including the UK, Canada, Japan, Germany, Russia and the US. The researchers found that 40 to 50 per cent of the differences in children’s motivation to learn could be explained by their genetic inheritance from their parents.

Chris Ball, 21, made the most gut-wrenching final goodbye video to his family before taking his own life. The three-minute footage shows Chris Ball repeatedly saying that no one should take the blame for his disease and expressing his unconditional love for his mother, four siblings and his girlfriend. Chris's brother Jayden and their stepfather found Chris's body along with a USB stick containing the video sitting on top of a piece of paper which simply said: 'Mum and Dad, please watch'His family have shared the heartbreaking video publicly to raise awareness of the crippling disease, which takes the lives of more young Australians than car accidents and skin cancer.

CEO Jonnie Williams. Among the gifts were almost $20,000 worth of designer clothing and accessories for Maureen McDonnell, vacations, golf outings and $15,000 for a daughter's wedding. Lawyers for both Bob McDonnell and his wife argued in separate briefs that the favors he did for Williams did not amount to 'official acts' covered by federal bribery law.

Researchers at the University of Sheffield analysed people with a body mass index of 30 or more - a recognised measure of obesity. They found obese people fall into one of six categories:. Scientists said their findings suggest that clinicians and policy makers should not target obese people as a whole, rather treat them according to the 'type' of obese person they are.

Researchers in North Carolina claim that zapping the brain with a mild electric current can boost creativity by nearly eight per cent. They tested their theory using a 10-Hertz current run through electrodes attached to the scalp on 20 volunteers to stimulate the brain's natural alpha wave oscillations. They then recorded the results using EEG.

It has emerged that detectives spent just over an hour at the repairman's house in Bonny Hills on the NSW north coast on Monday afternoon. The 63-year-old's home had been searched earlier in the year, in January and March, after it was revealed he was due to fix William's grandmother's washing machine around the time the boy vanished. William was last seen dressed in a Spider-Man suit and playing in his grandmother's yard in broad daylight in a quiet street in Kendall last September.

Dawn Marie Davies, from the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, warns sunbed users could be putting themselves at risk of contracting the sexually transmitted infection, herpes. Herpes is highly contagious and spreads from one person to another via skin-to-skin contact. It can reactivate every so often to cause a new episode of painful genital herpes.

It shows a driver behind the wheel of an AC & S truck tailgating, yelling and flashing his lights aggressively, nearly crashing into the back of a small Subaru car. Friends Cameron Rose and Bo Honna were the occupants of the Subaru and said they were perturbed when the truck driver crossed into their lane without using any indication. The incident started on Warringah Road and continued on for 8.5km.

Researchers measured the temperature of 'Hot Jupiter' HD 189733b. They found the temperature reaches up to 3,000°C in the atmosphere. And wind speeds are in excess of 620 miles per hour. The findings were made using a novel technique relying on sodium signals. The technique works by measuring the ‘sodium signal’ from distant worlds. When a planet passes in front of its star, the intensity of this signal varies.
Nasa scientists in California have revealed new images of the dwarf planet Ceres. They reveal new views of the two brightest spots in a crater. However, scientists are still not able to explain what they are. In particular, the images show the brightest spot and its companion standing out against the darker surroundings. Experts are still at a loss to explain the composition and source of the bright spots.
Poundland has become Europe's largest single-price discount retailer. Total revenue over the 12-month period grew 11.8 per cent to just over £1.1 billion. Poundland said it had opened 60 net new stores in the UK and Ireland and had a strong pipeline of openings.

Said staff will conduct bag checks on people they simply do not like. Comments follow revelations two TSA workers were fired for manipulating body scanners in Denver.

Truck drivers in Victoria are dealing drugs from the behind the wheel of 60-tonne rigs, using secretive codes over their radio systems. 156 truck drivers tested positive for drugs on Victoria's roads in the past year alone and it was revealed that they are using their log books to roll out lines and smoke ice. Victoria police revealed that there is a distribution network of speed, ice and marijuana operating in the trucking industry. One in 12 truckies are high on illicit substances when they are pulled over by Victorian police.

The government has approved funding for Cambridgeshire-based Mole Solutions to develop the idea as an alternative to the conventional systems of transporting goods by road. The plan aims to reduce the level of road freight within urban areas by using freight pipelines carrying goods in capsules to edge of town consolidation centres, where they would be collected. The development project is set to last nine months and if successful could be rolled out in other towns.

US scientists have found a way to use discarded corn husks and stalks to make cheap hydrogen fuel that doesn't pollute the environment like fossil fuels. The breakthrough could one day see the fuel being produced locally and drivers stopping to refuel their vehicles at roadside bioreactors instead of pumping petrol into their motor.
The Department of Veteran Affairs has banned organisations from using the word Anzac. Out of 384 applications that have inundated the department over the past 12 months about 80 per cent have been approved to use the term Anzac, which stands for the Australian and New Zealand Army Corp. The Church of Scientology, Woolworths, and online sites Teespring, Zazzle and Redbubble were reprimanded for using the term. Jerusalem syndrome is characterised by anxiety, agitation and nervousness. Sufferers are often consumed by a need to be clean, before donning a toga-like gown often made from hotel bed linen. The next stage sees sufferers overcome by the need to scream, or sing out loud psalms, verses from the Bible or religious hymns.

Flashgap app is free for iOS and Android devices and was created by Julian Kabab. Before a night out, one user creates an event and becomes that event's host. They can then add friends to the event at any point until the event ends. During the night, photos and videos can be taken using the app and each shot lasts for just three seconds. This 'evidence' is added to an album that collects photos and images taken by any attendee, and this album remains hidden until midday the day after the event. Only people who attended the event can see the album and users can only delete the photos they took themselves. Any photos deleted from the album are deleted from all users' accounts.
Hercules and Leo are the first animals in history to be covered by a writ of habeas corpus. They are currently living in a lab at Stony Brook University, Long Island. A representative of the university have been ordered to respond to a petition by the Nonhuman Rights Project. The decision by New York Supreme Court Justice Barbara Jaffe effectively recognises the chimpanzees as legal humans.

The 'goblins' are scientifically known as 'hoodoos' - rock protrusions consisting of relatively soft rock topped by harder stone that preserves each column's spire-like shape from weather erosion. Softer rock is removed by wind and water, leaving the unique constructions, which are further chiselled by water and dust erosion.
Sophie English was one of thousands of babies who was born at the height of the Vietnam War and adopted by an Australian family. There has been very little information to help Ms English find her birth mother who made the heartbreaking decision to give her up and for more than 40 years she has had many questions about her heritage. She was finally given a chance to find closure with ABC's Foreign Correspondent reporter Sally Sara who travelled with her to Vietnam in search of answers. The last time Ms English had seen her home country was when she was 10 months old.
LinX makes'multi-aperture' cameras small enough to fit into smartphones and tablets that come with depth-sensing technology. Rather than capturing a flat 2D image, the technology is able to sense the depth of each object in a photograph. Apple has confirmed the acquisition but not revealed any more details.

The last black model to cover the magazine was Rose Cordero in March 2010. British Vogue ended a 12-year run of failing to use a woman of colour on its cover.

Finley Lamb suffers from rare brain abnormality Periventricular Nodular Heterotopia. This means many of his 'grey matter' cells have not migrated to the correct position. Left him unable to walk and talk and with 90 per cent chance of developing Epilepsy. He is also highly likely to suffer heart, lung and bowel problems.

Garnet was established in the 1860s by miners looking for gold and silver, but was devastated by fire around 1912 and deserted a few years later. Now the U.S. Bureau of Land Management is looking for volunteers to help manage Garnet Ghost Town, a Montana mining town more that's more than 100 years old, and has been mostly abandoned for nearly that long. There are four positions, with some workers operating as tour guides and others keeping the grounds.
The Edwardian-style building and shopfront on Brunswick Street in Fitzroy was once owned by Wei Tang who was convicted in 2006 of keeping five Thai women as sex slaves. The brothel, formerly known as Club 417, has six bedrooms each with its own shower or spa, as well as a large lounge with a bar and a sitting room. The property stopped operating as a brothel in December 2013 and been vacant ever since.

Now runs marathons in aid of Every Mother Counts, an organization dedicated to making pregnancy and childbirth safe for mothers around the world.
Hannah Overton, 37, will not be tried on murder charges again in the death of her 4-year-old foster son, Andrew Burd. In September, the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals overturned Overton's capital murder conviction in the 2006 salt poisoning death of the boy, citing ineffective counsel at her 2007 trial. Overton has been behind bars for seven years, separated from her husband and five children who are being cared for by their father and home schooled by a supportive church community.

The men 'ordered the guards to lie on the ground, tied their hands behind their backs and marched them into nearby woods, before taking 275lbs of gold'The gold totaled $4.8 million, but the truck was carrying about $10 million worth of metal, so the thieves left half the load - mostly silver - behind. Police have previously said they suspected it was an inside job because the 18-wheeler truck - owned by transport company TransValue - pulled over when one of the two armed guards on board 'felt sick'They are now seeking a search warrant for the phones of the armed guard who felt sick because of the suspicious nature of the case.

SS City of Cairo was travelling from Bombay to England in 1942 when it was torpedoed by a U-boat 480 miles south of St Helena, taking 100 tons of rupees with it to the bottom of the ocean. It was long assumed that the vessel's cargo, belonging to the UK Treasury, would be lost forever such was the complexity of the task facing salvage experts. Underwater company Deep Ocean Search used powerful sonar to locate the vessel on the sea floor.

UK researchers studied the asteroid impact 66 million years ago. They found the heat near the impact site in Mexico was not intense enough to ignite plant material. A heat pulse lasted less than a minute, too short to set plants alight. It suggests our understanding of the mass extinction event that wiped out the dinosaurs may not be as complete as thought.

When High There! first launched two months ago, it could only be downloaded by users in the US who live in states that have legalised cannabis but a global version was rolled out yesterday. The app quickly became popular in New York, California and Colorado, with 41,000 downloads in the first six weeks.

Trade was taking place between East Asia and the New World hundreds of years before Christopher Columbus arrived in the area in 1492. Bronze-working had not been developed at this time in Alaska, and researchers believe the artefacts were created in China, Korea or Yakutia. The discovery was made after archaeologists found what they believe to be a bronze and leather buckle, dating to around A.D. 600.

Schwartz asked them to answer the question 'I wish my teacher knew...' on a piece of paper and turn it in to her anonymously or share it with the class. Schwartz shared some of the notes on Twitter, and soon teachers across the nation started trying out the lesson plan and posting their own results online.

Psychologists at New York University have been trying to gain an understanding about how the brain stores memories for 'emotionally neutral events' that gain significance through subsequent experience. This study focused on how our brains remember emotionally arousing stimuli, such as evocative imagery or traumatic events. In particular, the study looked into how the September 11 terrorist attacks in the the US affect memory retention.

The new policy allows for an American traveler who has been denied boarding a commercial airliner to petition the U.S. Transportation Security Administration once to find out whether he or she is on the no-fly list and a second time for an unclassified explanation. In some cases, the government will not be able to provide an explanation because of national security concerns. The changes partially lift a veil of secrecy enshrouding a policy that has been a centerpiece of the government's counterterrorism efforts since September 2001 terror attacks.

Anna Duggar, who is married to eldest Duggar Josh, is pregnant with the couple's fourth child, a baby girl due in July.
Matt Mooney wanted to stay true to the materials that became the foundation for his home. The 3,700 sq ft home, dubbed 'PV14,' boasts a 40ft long swimming pool on the ground floor. The home also features a 1,400 sq ft roof deck that can fit up to 150 people and a 360 degree view of White Rock Lake and downtown Dallas.
Dental kits allow people to carry out their own fillings and repair caps and crowns. The kits can cost as little as £5 or even be bought in pound shops. They are intended to provide a temporary solution for lost fillings or broken caps. But more and more people are said to be buying the kits due to the price of NHS treatment.
KFC's quiz contains a total of 30 questions which mostly ask applicants to rank their response from'strongly agree' to strongly disagree. Head of Human Resources, Robert Phipps, assured it was designed to rank the thousands of applicants that apply fo jobs with the company. 'I wouldn't say it's deeply scientific, but it's reasonably scientific,' he said. The questions seek guidance as to how potential employees might react in workplace situations.
It's the worst storm to hit the NSW coast in a decade, but what everyone in the region wants to know is why no warning was given that it was going to be this bad. Emergency services admitted on Tuesday they were shocked by the severity of the storm and that their teams were overwhelmed by a weather system that changed very rapidly. The Hunter Valley was one of the worst-hit areas in NSW and this car in Blacksmiths got the brunt of the weather.
Frank Abagnale was played by Leonardo Di Caprio in the 2002 film Catch Me If You Can. In the film he posed as a doctor, a lecturer, a lawyer and an airline pilot. He has spent the rest of his career working with the FBI on fraud detection and prevention.
Sporty Pippa Middleton was spotted out jogging in London today. The 31-year-old is preparing to take part in a 54-mile cycle from London to Brighton to raise money for charity.
Jamyra Gallmon of Washington was arrested last week and charged with first-degree murder while armed for allegedly killing David Messerschmitt, 30, on February 9 at the Donovan Hotel. Her roommate - and alleged girlfriend - 19-year-old Dominique Johnson was arrested on Wednesday and is accused of being an accomplice. According to a police affidavit filed in court on Thursday, she stole just $40 and the victim's Metro SmarTrip card.
More than 100 tonnes of dead fish were found floating in the water near Huizhou City on Friday morning. Workers had rushed to clear the lake, using plastic baskets and nets to scoop them out, creating a huge mountain of rotting fish.

The school council launched an investigation, which included a search of Mr Barr's computer, after the photograph appeared on the social media site Snapchat.
Former Scottish First Minister wants to make a return to the Commons as MP for Gordon. Alex Salmond has chosen to stand in the Gordon constituency, where veteran Lib Dem Sir Malcolm Bruce is standing down. Polls suggest the Lib Dems face near-wipeout in Scotland, with senior figures under threat from a surge in support for the SNP.
Raymond Allen, 87, opened the first KFC franchise in Preston, Lancashire, in 1965. He is only a handful of people in the world to know the secret recipe for the fast-food chain's chicken. He said the company has strayed so far from its original concept it's been 'ruined' and would never set foot in one again.
DNA analysis of the bones of 'Altamura Man' in a cave in Altamura, Italy, has revealed that they belong to a Neanderthal who fell into the cave 128,000 to 187,000 years ago. The bones were found fused to the walls of the cave in Lamalunga, near Altamura. DNA extracted from the bones matches that of other Neanderthal skeletons.
Friedrich Brandt, 23, was a member of George III's German Legion. He was killed by Napoleon’s forces and was found with a musket ball between his ribs. No complete skeleton had ever been retrieved from the battle of Waterloo.
Scientists analysed 57 species in the region and found that the majority of populations had diminished as a result of the nuclear accident. They found that one breed in particular had plummeted from several hundred before the 2011 disaster to just a few dozen today. This is despite radiation levels in the area starting to fall. And comparing it to Chernobyl could reveal what the future holds.
Billions of barrel jellyfish have been spotted in Devon and Cornwall waters. They are each the size of a dustbin lid and can grow up to six feet long. Experts believe they have been attracted by warmer waters and lack of predators.
The xylella fastidiosa bacteria has ravaged olive trees in Puglia region. It has contributed to a 35 percent drop in the region's olive oil production last year. The bacteria causes plants to dry out, leaving shrivelled stumps incapable of bearing fruit.
Jessica Howard, 23, denounced 'night stalker' Clive Howard, 57, for his string of assaults on six women over 28 years. She told him that the catastrophic impact of his attack could never be put into words and has destroyed her life. Howard admitted seven counts of rape, three of kidnap and one of attempted rape at an earlier hearing.
Accident is believed to have happened at about 8.15am in the east of the island. The single-engine Piper PA-32 crashed shortly after take-off in the Punta Cana region. It is believed the pilot was attempting to make an emergency landing when the plane struck the ground in a golf course adjacent to the airport and burst into flames. The plane was en route to the Samana Peninsula off the north coast with a pilot and six passengers. Local police said they believed four of the passengers were tourists from Spain and two were from Britain.

Labour leader insists SNP MPs would not be able to dictate policy, even if he fails to win a majority and is reliant on them to stay in Number 10. Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon this morning said Labour could only govern with the support of the SNP – and laid out what the party must do to get it. She demanded an end to government cuts, higher welfare spending and big hikes in the minimum wage in return for propping up a Labour government. But Miliband rejected claims the SNP would be 'calling the shots' if Labour did not have a majority.
Abraham Lincoln was shot in Ford's Theatre in Washington D.C. on April 14, 1865 by pro-Confederacy actor, John Wilkes Booth. The red, worn chair has been on display at The Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan, for 85 years. On April 15, it will be removed from its encasing to be displayed for the 150th anniversary of the assassination.

He was speaking on a film called ‘Space Special Forces’ during a tour of Russia’s main centre for aerospace intelligence in Krasnoznamensk, near Moscow. Susan Farmer, 37, from Eddy, Texas, weighs 43st (605lbs) and was told by doctors to lose half her body weight or face early death. At her heaviest, Susan weighed 43st and was unable to walk for longer than 30 seconds at a time.
Average Briton enjoys 884 cups of tea each year - or enough to fill two bathtubs, survey finds. YouGov poll of more than 2,000 Britons revealed we consume an average of 17 cups each week. Almost a third of women turn to a cuppa to make them feel better when they are unwell.
The mysterious ‘Antarctic BW29 signal was recorded near the Orkney Islands, South Shetland Islands, and Antarctic Peninsula by scientists led by Jennifer Trickey of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, at the University of California, in La Jolla, California. It could belong to a strap-toothed whale, a southern bottlenosed whale or a Gray’s beaked whale, according to the study. Experts are sure the noise isn’t made by Arnoux's beaked whales, because the signal doesn't match their songs.
Mumia Abu-Jamal, 60, is serving a life sentence in prison for the murder of a Philadelphia police officer Daniel Faulkner in 1981. Third graders in Orange, New Jersey, and high school students in the Philadelphia Student Union sent him letters wishing him well after he was hospitalized last week.
Bill Dudley has worked at McDonald's in Mold, Flintshire, north Wales, for nine years. Great grandfather and Second World War veteran has no plans to quit the fast-food joint. He joined the team nine years ago after growing 'bored' pottering around the house.

Temperatures are due to rise throughout today peaking at 22C (72F) tomorrow. That is 11C warmer than the UK April average and would beat the current 2015 high of 20.7C (69F) on Easter Sunday in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire. 22C is also better than the 18C forecast in Marbella, 16C in Rhodes and 10C in Istanbul.
Law allows Oklahoma to use nitrogen gas to kill death row prisoners if lethal injections aren't available. The method involves pumping a chamber full of nitrogen and leaving a prisoner's body to die from lack of oxygen. It has been touted as 'foolproof' by supporters, in the wake of botched lethal injections.
Reconnaissance unit is moving from Robertson Barracks in Swanton Morley to Catterick, North Yorkshire, after 15 years. More than 4,000 people, including hundreds of school children, lined the streets of Dereham to cheer on the departing troops. The Light Dragoons will hand over barracks to another unit in the summer after a decade in the town.
Around 20 million people in the UK are expected to suffer hayfever symptoms this summer, up a third from last year, experts told MailOnline. By 2030, Dr Jean Emberlin predicts there will be 31.8 million sufferers as the situation will worsen. Hayfever is an allergic reaction to pollen and spores.

All four are the offspring of immigrant parents who moved to America - from Bulgaria, Somalia or Nigeria. Now they hope to use the opportunities for good - whether its effecting positive social change, improving education across the world or becoming a neurosurgeon.

But when it doubled to £600 the money was either late or stopped being paid at all. Border was sentenced to 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, at Nottingham Crown Court.
Primatologists at Iowa State University recorded 300 hunts by chimps in Fongoli, Sénégal, and found female chimps were using tools to capture prey in 60 per cent of the observations. The research suggests that early female humans were perhaps the first to begin fashioning simple tools to help them catch prey.

He is the lone officer among 13 who fired their weapons that night who is charged criminally because prosecutors say he stood on the hood and opened fire four seconds after the other officers had stopped shooting. He faces a maximum sentence of 25 years in prison if convicted.

He refused to admit to the 2011 crime which he said makes him look like an evil, horrible person.

Castle Toward, near Dunoon, was used to ready soldiers for landing at a beach and was commissioned as HMS Brontosaurus in 1942. Overlooking the Clyde estuary and with easy access to the sloping shoreline, the castle was deemed an ideal training ground for thousands of British troops. Allied soldiers would spend a week of intensive training at the castle.

Photographs taken with the very first'secret' handheld camera will go on display on Saturday at the State Library. The Detective Camera was produced between 1883 and 1887 using a dry negative which was already loaded into the device. The camera was loaded, focused and ready to take a photograph at around six feet away. This was the first time people were confronted with the idea of being photographed without their knowledge.

Holmesburg Prison in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was filled with violent riots, bloody beatings and most shocking of all - the cruel chemical experimentation on its inmates. Since its construction in 1895, some of the country's most dangerous criminals walked the halls of Holmesburg prison. Haunting images published in 2011 proved that government doctors used the jail to test chemical substances on inmates and disabled American citizens.

Kent Sprouse, 42, was sent to death row for a 2002 shootout at a Ferris, Texas, convenience store that killed police officer Harry Steinfeldt III and customer Pedro Moreno, 38. Sprouse admitted almost immediately after he was arrested that he killed a police officer and another man outside a Dallas-area convenience store. Wigry National Park, in north-east Poland, is the furthest outreach of the Masurian Lakes (Poland’s Lake District), and the most sparsely populated. The area is unspoiled, but it is also exceedingly well set-up for outdoor pursuits.

Known as 'Ogle-2014-BLG-0124Lb,' the gas giant was detected by the Spitzer Space Telescope and the Ogle Warsaw Telescope in Chile. It is half as massive as Jupiter and could help astronomers gain a better understanding of the distribution of planets in the Milky Way. The planet was discovered using a technique known as microlensing. This happens when one star happens to pass in front of another, and its gravity acts as a lens to magnify the more distant star's light.

In 84 days from November 2013 to January 2014, the area around Azle, Texas, shook with 27 magnitude two or greater earthquakes. Scientists believe these earthquakes were the result of high-pressure injection of drilling wastewater into the ground. This adds to other studies that linked injecting wastewater from energy wells to a tremendous jump in earthquakes in Oklahoma and southern Kansas.
The last Plantagenet king of England was described by William Shakespeare as a 'poisonous bunch-back'd toad' in his play depicting the monarch. But research on the king's skeleton discovered under a council car park in Leicester revealed that this may have been an exaggeration of a spine deformity known as scoliosis. Genetic analysis showed that Richard III almost certainly had blue eyes and likely had blonde hair - although it may have darkened with age.

Airline Visual Identity 1945-1975 is a 436-page book featuring adverts for Pan Am, British Overseas Airways Corp (BOAC) and Continental. The adverts were created for the biggest airlines of the day, including TWA and Canadian Pacific, which no longer exist. The book uses 17 colours, five types of varnishes and two methods of foil printing and embossing to replicate their work as accurately as possible.
Copper coin dates from the Iron Age almost 2,300 years ago and is smaller than a penny. It was found in silt after the River Avon burst its banks between Bristol and Bath. Experts have dated the coin to between 300 BC and 264 BC and say it came from the Western Mediterranean - probably Sardinia or ancient Carthage. Find suggests that the village of Saltford, where it was found, was on a major trade route long before Roman times.

Cancer that has spread and is incurable, known as secondary breast cancer, kills 1,000 women every month. Researchers from Manchester University working with drug development company Evgen Pharma, have developed a new combination of drugs which could overcome this problem. They are testing the drug Sulforadex in the most common type of breast cancer affecting 70 per cent of patients.
Survey of 757 parents was carried out by Mumsnet, the UK’s largest internet community for parents. It found 37 per cent of parents had not told their children how to dial 999, with 53 per cent claiming they had never even considered teaching them. Nearly half - 46 per cent - insisted their children were not mature enough to know about who to call in an emergency. 65 per cent said their children did not know the difference between 999 and 911, the emergency number in the US.

Two Brazil nuts provide 100 per cent of our daily required dose of 75 micrograms. Selenium is needed for the production of antibodies, important for a healthy immune system, and the hormone thyroxine, needed to regulate metabolism. You need to eat just ten almonds to get your daily requirement of calcium (700mg)

Eve Addison, 24, developed a strange swelling in her collarbone whenever she drank gin and tonic. She assumed she must have an allergy, but when she developed night sweats and a rash, she saw her GP. Tests revealed she was suffering Hodgkin Lymphoma - cancer of the lymphatic system. Most common symptom of Hodgkin lymphoma is one or more painless swellings in the neck, armpit or groin. These swellings are enlarged lymph nodes - oval-shaped glands that help the body recognise and fight germs.

Arizona is leading the way with plans to create artificial rain clouds by flying planes over the Rockies and seeding the sky with silver iodide. They hope the technology will allow them to mitigate some of the worst impacts of climate change – but not everyone is convinced. The process of cloud seeding was first proposed in the 1940s at the General Electric labs in Schenectady, New York.

Scientists at Brandeis University in Massachusetts believe all-nighters to cram before an exam won't work because the process converting short-term memories to long-term memory is best carried out when a person is asleep. They focused their research on dorsal paired medial neurons, well-known memory consolidators in fruit flies.
All but one of 10 former Atlanta public school educators convicted in a widespread conspiracy to inflate student scores on standardized tests were sentenced to jail time on Tuesday. Fulton County Superior Court Judge Jerry Baxter had delayed sentencing by a day and encouraged all to negotiate deals with prosecutors, but only two agreed to deals. He called the cheating scandal 'the sickest thing that's ever happened in this town'A state investigation found that as far back as 2005, educators from the 50,000-student Atlanta school system fed answers to students or erased and changed answers on tests.
Tavon Watson, 24, was doing 100mph at the Exotic Driving Experience at Walt Disney World in Orlando when he slammed the $220,000 Lamborghini on the passenger side into a guardrail. Florida Highway Patrol Sgt Kim Montes revealed Tuesday that the guardrail damaged the Italian car on the east side of the passenger door. The FHP is now investigating whether cars at the private track are set up to travel in the opposite, clockwise direction of the guardrails.
Michelle Heale of Tom's River, New Jersey claims she was trying to burp Mason Hess when he began choking on his applesauce and that his neck snapped when she took him off her shoulder. Heale was charged with murder and endangering the welfare of a child after a medical examiner determined the boy died as a result of homicide caused by blunt cerebral trauma. The prosecution has argued that Heale shook the child to death. The mother of twins, who were in the next room when the incident happened and then just three years old, was able to keep custody of her children.
As many as 20 per cent of people suffer with the occasional single mouth ulcer. These small painful ulcers usually last no more than ten days and require no treatment. The pain can severely impact on quality of life, as eating and drinking are significantly affected.

In 10 battleground constituencies polled by Tory peer Lord Ashcroft, Ukip's vote has fallen in nine. Support for Mr Farage's party has more than halved in two seats and by more than a third in most of the others. Comes after a leaked poll revealed Mr Farage is on course to lose his own Parliamentary election battle in Ukip's heartland in Kent.

James and Hope Ben Canaan left the Gloriavale Christian Community, located at Lake Haupiri on New Zealand's West Coast, with their twelve children and few worldly possessions last month. The Ben Canaans are adapting well to life in the wider community, a relative said, with the father accepting a farm job and the family moving into a home with modern appliances. Gloriavale is a Christian community of around 500 people who follow a literal interpretation of the New Testament and reject the outside world.

Rebecca Calder, 24, who was jailed for a year today, went out drinking on the same night she used her victims' bank card to withdraw large amounts of money. At her peak she was draining up to £300 a day from her disabled victims' accounts, spending it on nights out and items such as shoes. Calder had stolen more than £5,000 from the savings of the elderly couple who suffered from mental and physical disabilities.
The USS Oklahoma capsized after being hit by nine torpedoes during the December 7, 1941 surprise attack from Japanese forces. Altogether, 429 sailors and Marines onboard were killed. Only 35 were identified in the years immediately after the attack. The military is acting now, nearly 75 years after the men died, because advances in forensic science and technology have made it possible to identify more remains.

Father-of-one Terry died at the scene while Watson was rushed to Celebration Hospital near Lake Buene Vista for treatment where he was later declared stable. The day out at the track was a present from Watson's wife and he posted a picture of himself next to a Ferrari on the tarmac just hours before the fatal collision.

His internal assessments were secretly downgraded to make him appear unworthy, tribunal heard. He said he was left 'upset' and 'angry' after being penalised because he was black. Despite his treatment, Mr Lungu is still serving as a PC with the force.

Sudan the Northern White Rhino is the last surviving male of his species. He is the target of poachers looking to sell rhino horn which can make up to £47,000 a kilo. Rhino horn is the third largest illegal trade in the world, after arms and drugs.

Activision Blizzard has announced plans to resurrect the popular video game franchise later this year. Called Guitar Hero Live, the revamped game features a redesigned guitar, live-action actors and an online music video network. It will cast players as an up-and-coming guitarist in a fictitious band. Instead of playing along with computer-generated characters, wannabe rockers will see a first-person view of their band mates and audiences portrayed by human actors. The game will be released in the autumn for the PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Wii U and mobiles.

Anne-Louise van den Nieuwenhof was diagnosed with a rare bone and soft tissue cancer, called Ewing’s sarcoma, aged just five. Her parents were told she only had three months to live and she was told she wouldn't live to see her sixth birthday, let alone have her own children. She went on to defy all the odds against her, eventually moving to Canada where she worked as a nurse and began raising her own family. She tragically died during a routine hospital check-up for her baby girl Elizabeth Kelly, near her home in Rossland, British Columbia in Canada, six days after giving birth on March 10.

Park Crescent West, next to Regents Park in London, was designed by John Nash in the early 19th century to be grand houses for the friends and family of the Prince Regent. The Grade I listed terrace was restored in 1960 and replaced with offices and residential accommodation. Developer PCW Property Holdings paid £105million for the crescent in 2013 and has now submitted fresh plans to demolish it and rebuild it as ultra-posh apartments. Residents who live behind the site are furious at the proposals, claiming years of noise and disruption will ruin their lives.

The dress - a jacket and full skirt ensemble - was worn in several key scenes in the 1939 movie, including when Scarlett O'Hara encounters Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable, and when she gets attacked in the shanty town.
Red squirrels have returned to one of Britain's most stunning beauty spots after 16-year absence. Native reds have been almost wiped out in the country, except for a few pockets in the north of England, the Isle of Wight and Scotland after rival grey squirrels arrived from America in the 19th century. Numbers of the reds, popularly illustrated in the Beatrix Potter Squirrel Nutkin books, have been rapidly dwindling thanks in large part to the squirrel pox virus carried by greys. Experts say a lack of habitats caused them to disappear from the area.

The Manchester flight was scheduled to use a smaller plane with nothing but coach. The Boston flight, though, used a larger aircraft with 12 first class seats.

Eddie Raymond Tipton, 51, of Norwalk, Iowa, was charged with two felony counts of fraud for illegally playing the lottery and having a friend collect his prize. Now prosecutors say he used an intricate system to make sure he would win. They argue he installed a self-destructing hack program to ensure the Random Number Generator selected his number in December 2010, and that he tampered with security cameras in the building so he would not be caught installing the program.
Experts from Centre for International Research in the Humanities and Social Sciences (CIRHUS) in New York City studied neolithic ornaments to understand how farming spread. They examined some 200 bead-type objects found at more than 400 European sites over a 3,000-year period. They found that the pathways of the spread of farming are less clear than previously thought.

Jan said that her tattoos are a memorial and a way for her to carry her children with her. 'Shell was just such a gorgeous girl. It's a loss that leaves a hole in your heart that's never filled again,' she said.

They are dragged onto ships where they are clubbed and skinned for their fur. HSI says the baby seals are 'dying a violent death for fur products that nobody is buying'

None* app gives users only one clue to get started and a keyboard to type their guesses. There are no images, music, animations, sound effects or hints to help users, or indication of what the purpose of the game is exactly. The app has a pitch black screen and a single clue written in white text, as well as showing a small keyboard. The questions are relatively simple to start with, including maths questions and some that have clear answers, but then extend to name associations.

The aluminium battery was created at Stanford University, California. It is said to be the first high-performance aluminium battery that is 'fast-charging, long-lasting and inexpensive'It consists of a negatively charged anode made of aluminum and a positively charged graphite cathode along with an ionic liquid electrolyte. It can also withstand more than 7,500 cycles without any loss of capacity.

Alan Turing wrote the notes at the Government Code and Cypher School at Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire, in 1942. He is best known for his contribution to cracking the code used by the Germans in their Enigma machines during the Second World War. The notebook, in which he details his work on the foundations of mathematical notation and computer science, was sold for $1,025,000 (£698,000) at Bonhams in New York.

The 56-page book bought in Cambridge contains Turing's thoughts on the 'Leibniz notation dx/dy'It was written at the Bletchley Park code-breaking headquarters in 1942 and paved the way for computer science. It is believed to be the only extensive Turing manuscript known to exist, auctioneer said. Turing committed suicide in 1954 and was gay at a time when homosexuality was illegal.

25-ft long wreckage was discovered floating west of Ona Beach in Lincoln County at about 9.30am on Thursday. Biologists found live yellowtail jack fish, native to Japan, inside the floating debris and are being housed in the Oregon Coast Aquarium.

Department of Twin Research, which hosts the biggest adult twin registry in the UK, recently performed a poll of voting preferences. Aim was to explore how much nature and nurture influence our party political allegiances and potential voting preferences so we can draw broader conclusions about people’s voting habits. Identical twins share 100 per cent of their genes, while non-identical twins - like non-twin siblings - share about 50 per cent.
Skeletons were found on top of one another in the tomb from Korea’s Silla Dynasty. Experts believe the tomb was intended for a noblewoman and believe the man she is lying with may have been killed so he could be buried with her. The tomb is made of soil and stone and was discovered last December in a neighbourhood of Gyeongju City.

Poll of 2,000 Britons found 68 per cent had hurt themselves doing odd jobs or decorating. Two in five had injured their back, one in 5 had cut themselves and one in ten had suffered side effects from inhaling chemical fumes. Men are a third more likely than women to try to cut corners when doing a job.

Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - our distant ancestors - to move to new regions.
The Babel Bike was designed by London-based Crispin Sinclair. He is seeking £50,000 ($74,000) of funding on Indiegogo to bring his dream to fruition. The bike has a small wheel at the front and a larger one on the back, with a lockable white bar connecting them that doubles as storage for the bike’s innards. At the front of the bike are two steel foot protectors, which are detachable and can also be used as a bike lock.

London Mayor has been largely invisible at a national level despite being the second best known Tory in the country. Speculation is high that a result of the exchange could be the official removal of Cuba from the State Department's list of state terror sponsors. That removal would also lift some economic sanctions on Cuba.
Holly Barber, 25, from Manchester, woke up feeling unwell and with chest and neck pains. She chalked it down to heavy drinking a few days before, but when she started coughing up blood she knew it was something serious. She rushed to hospital, where doctors found 13 pulmonary embolisms, blood clots blocking the main artery of her lungs, killing the tissue and stopping her from breathing properly. She now takes blood-thinning medication to prevent future clots, but the shock of the ordeal has led her to completely change her lifestyle.

Hundreds of African immigrants have begun arriving in their home countries after fleeing the bloody violence that has swept across South Africa. Among them were some 400 Zimbabweans who were packed onto buses to escape the anti-immigrant attacks that have left seven people dead in recent days. The boy's mother, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide. But the charge was dropped after she told police she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends and later had a stillbirth.
Julius Caesar collapsed at the battle of Thapsus in 46BC and had to be carried to safety. Historians have long believed this was result of an epileptic attack, highlighting other symptoms such as vertigo, dizziness and weakness in his limbs. New research suggests that the Roman general may in fact have been suffering from a series of mini-strokes that affected both his mental and physical state. Doctors at Imperial College London came to conclusion after taking a new look at Caesar's symptoms described in Greek and Roman documents.
Baroness Hale of Richmond said she wanted to see bitterness taken out of most matrimonial disputes so a person does not need to be held at fault in order to obtain a divorce. Around 120,000 couples divorce in England and Wales each year and those who want to divorce quickly are encouraged to cite unfaithfulness or unreasonable behaviour.

The tunnels were dug into sandstone cliffs along the River Mersey in Stockport, Greater Manchester, in the 1930s. They were originally intended to provide car parking spaces, but were redeveloped as an air raid shelter during the Second World War. The shelter was so popular that local officials had to issue season tickets limiting the number of people who would be allowed to seek refuge there.

William Ziegler, now 39, was jailed in 2001 for the killing of Russell Allen Baker, an acquaintance of his who was found dead next to his house in Mobile the previous year. In 2012 his conviction was overturned by Judge Sarah Stewart who blasted his initial trial, pointing out that his lawyers were substandard, a key witness later recounted her testimony, and a juror lied about his views on the death penalty. Today he agreed to plead guilty to aiding and abetting murder, with the judge sentencing him to the 15 years and 50 days he has already served.

Laura Everley, 36, was diagnosed with ovarian cancer after seeing a post on Facebook. She had been suffering from bloating, back pain, constipation and frequently needing the loo. Had previously suffered irritable bowel syndrome and endometriosis, so put symptoms down to those conditions. But when she stumbled across a post describing all her symptoms, she realised it could be cancer. Tests revealed she had an aggressive ovarian tumour - and the disease had begun to spread. In October 2014, she underwent a hysterectomy to remove her womb and her ovaries.

Optimal case was designed by Israel-based Amited. Sensors in the case monitor the phone's temperature and if it gets too hot, Optimal will cool the device using two built-in micro-fans. Astronomers say the unique event happened in an ancient cluster of stars at the edge of the Milky Way galaxy. A white dwarf star is the dense core of a star like the Sun that has run out of nuclear fuel. This means that, for close encounters, the gravitational pull of the star and associated tides, caused by the difference in gravity's pull on the near and far side of the planet, are greatly enhanced.

More than 60 firefighters battled the blaze, which erupted on July 13, 2013, as frightened passers-by watched on. The girl who started the fire is said to have dropped a cigarette while standing near the shop's fire exit which rolled underneath the door and set boxes alight. She was originally charged with arson being reckless as to whether life was endangered, but was cleared having been due to stand trial on Monday.

Residents living on two surrounding roads have been making four-and-a-half mile round trips, sometimes by taxi, to collect their mail.

The Directorate of Religious Affairs for Turkey has decreed that Muslims are allowed to use toilet paper. The rules for how Muslims should relieve themselves, called the Qadaa al-Haajah, was established in the times before toilet paper or toilet seats were invented. It states that the use of the material for hygiene is acceptable but water was preferable.
Measurements made by the European space probe Philae, which landed on comet 67P in November, show the comet's core isn't magnetised. Some astrophysicists have suggested that magnetism might have been responsible for aligning and then binding together rocks into larger boulders during the early stages of planet formation. But the team led by Hans-Ulrich Auster at the Technical University of Braunschweig, Germany, said their data don't support this theory.

Last week, the US Justice Department said prison officials must treat an inmate’s gender identity condition just as they would treat any other medical or mental health condition.

People walking along Somerton Beach, southwest of Adelaide, found a deceased fully-clothed man aged about 45 lying on the shore on December 1, 1948. A post-mortem determined that the man had died of poisoning but police and coronial investigations were unable to identify the body due to several factors including that the poison used to kill him was undetectable. Even a handwritten note found hidden in the pocket of a man's trousers did not provide any clues to the identity of the body.
The 630ft New York Wheel will be able to carry as many as 1,400 passengers at a time. It will include mobile bar cars, a 20-seat restaurant, a 4-D ride on the ground and an LED light show every night. Ticket prices will range from an estimated $25 to $30 (£17 to £20)
Scientists at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School have developed a device that can be attached to the camera of an iPhone 4s device. The device works by using microbeads that specifically target molecules that sit on the surface of cancer cells. When clumped around a cell, the beads alter the way the light is scattered by the sample. They produce distinctive diffraction patterns in the image if clumped together. The researchers claim it can asses 100,000 cells from a single image in around 45 minutes.
Jerry Grayson, 59, was involved in rescuing sailors during the Fastnet Yacht Rescue in 1979. He set himself the task of tracking down every aircraft he ever flew as part of Royal Navy rescue missions during the 1970s. He travelled 23,000 miles to find every chopper he had ever flown - but found one had been converted into a posh camping facility. The Wessex Mark 1 now resides between a gypsy caravan and an old Routemaster bus near Ditchling, Sussex.

Police believe the man had been left in the woods all week - with nothing but a bible and a blanket - and was exposed to the rain and cold and to wild animals. Parler was initially charged with aggravated assault, kidnapping and neglect of a care-dependent person, and police have now added attempted murder to the list. Police said they did not expect to arrest Parler until she was cleared for release from the hospital and charged in Maryland as a fugitive.

Australian internet companies will have to reveal names, IP addresses and residential addresses of 4,726 people who uploaded the film The Dallas Buyers Club online illegally. The Federal Court ruled on Tuesday that Australian internet companies, including iiNet and other ISPs, should hand over the names and IP addresses of those who illegally shared the film. Dr Zoe Waller, 31, suffers from the skin condition dermatographia. This is a type of urticaria, or hives - where a raised, itchy rash appears on the skin at the slightest pressure. It is thought to be caused when the cells under the surface of the skin release histamines as part of an allergic reaction, causing the skin to swell. Her students are required to learn 100 drugs for their course and each day, she will draw a new one on her skin.

11 self-contained small satellites, each about the size of a large shoebox, will be tucked inside the Orion spacecraft's stage adapter. Three missions will use these small satellites during the test flight to help develop technologies for astronauts travelling to deep space. Near-Earth Asteroid Scout, using solar sail propulsion, will fly by a small asteroid, taking pictures and making observations. BioSentinel will use yeast to detect, measure, and compare the impact of deep space radiation on living organisms over long durations beyond Low-Earth Orbit.

Britain ranked only the 27th best country in the world for health and wellness in an international league table looking at a range of living standards. Obesity levels were the main factor pushing the UK down the health rankings. Overall, the UK came 11th in the table of countries with the highest standards of prosperity, health and tolerance, putting Britain outside the top ten most civilised and best-off people.

President Barack Obama has held the fewest number of state dinners since Harry S. Truman, who left office 62 years ago. In his first six years, Obama held just seven state dinners and will hold at least two more this year: for the leaders of Japan, on April 28, and China, later in the year. A White House state dinner is the highest diplomatic honour the U.S. reserves for allies and other countries.

Study uncovered a link between belief in God and other societal characteristics, such as a strong social hierarchy. Scientists suggest that religious beliefs help people cope in inhospitable habitats. Communities that believe in a high, controlling God or gods who enforce a moral code, tend to live in politically complex groups.

Italian coffee giant Lavazza joined forces with the Turin-based engineering company Argotec and the Italian Space Agency to provide a specially designed machine for use off the planet. It is the first coffee machine able to work in micro gravity on the ISS, where the principles that regulate the fluid dynamics of liquids and mixtures are very different from those typical on Earth. It uses a 'capsule system' to fill plastic pouches with espresso and other hot drinks such as tea. The machine can also be used to rehydrate food.

They combined a standard drug already used, ipilimumab, with another, nivolumab, to treat skin cancer. After just one dose of the two drugs, the 49-year-old woman reported her tumour 'kind of dissolved'She was treated as part of a clinical trial to test effects of a new drugs combination on patients with advanced melanoma.

Documents suggest methyl bromide may have been improperly applied in various locations in Puerto Rico, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday. EPA regional administrator Judith Enck said the agency and Puerto Rico's Department of Agriculture are investigating where and when the pesticide was used and how much was applied. Methyl Bromide, which is odorless, can be fatal or cause serious damage to the central nervous system and respiratory system.
Sarah Flower says it's time to ditch vitamin pills for a diet rich in clean, fresh and unprocessed foods. The cleaner your diet - using fresh ingredients and cooking at home - the less likely you are to need to rely on supplements to boost your health, she says.

US researchers say very few weight loss plans have solid evidence to back up their claims. Results suggest only a few programmes have shown users lose more weight than those not using them. A spring storm that had doused Northern California for the previous 24 hours arrived in Southern California on Tuesday night, bringing mostly light but necessary rainfall. Thousands were without power for several hours because of the storm, and the Los Angeles Dodgers had a rare rain delay on the second day of the season. Earlier in the day, the unusually cold spring storm brought heavy rain and hail to parts of Northern California and coated the mountains in snow - a welcome respite but one that will do little to ease the historic drought, forecasters say.

Maglev trains use magnets to lift the carriages above the track. This eliminates the need for wheels and therefore any incidence of friction. The technology promises a ride that's smoother, quieter and almost twice as fast as traditional high-speed rail.

Tourist board survey found that Scotland held 5.54 marriages per 1,000 - making it most popular part of the UK in which to tie the knot.

Currently around 39,000 Australian children under the age of seven are not vaccinated putting them at risk of catching severe diseases.

It would also require 'temporary cash assistance' recipients to hold down jobs, look for work or enroll in job training programs. The Brownback administration has signaled its support for the measure.

Louisa Steckenreuter, 35, a mother to two young children, Darcy, 13, and Tilda, 2, was diagnosed with Osteosarcoma, a rare form of cancer last year. The mother-of-two turned to a new drug, Keytruda, to help fight off the deadly disease. It works differently to chemotherapy, which attacks all the cells in the system, even healthy ones. The medication costs $6000 a month, and is not subsidised on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

The research focused on POMC neurons, which are a structure called the hypothalamus, that send and receive signals to regulate appetite. They are a central node of the brain's means for regulating body weight, in response to influences from the hormone leptin. When they are absent, or not working properly, animals and humans grow dangerously obese. The new research could lead to pills that will be able to quieten that voice or increase its volume.

The septum ring isn't a new trend - the process of piercing the wall between the two nostrils has been done for years. It was a coming-of-age ritual for some North American tribes - the boys would be given the nose ring when they became a man, the Shawnee leaders Tecumseh and Tenskwatawa both had them.

Bergen-Belsen was the final resting place of 50,000 Jews, Gypsies, homosexuals, Nazi opponents and those with disabilities, sent to an inhuman death by Adolf Hitler and his demented regime. Diarist Anne Frank, and her sister Margot, also died here. Shortly after liberation by British and Canadian troops in 1945, it was torched, and at least part of that suffering was destroyed forever.

A monster crocodile has been caught devouring a one metre long lizard in one bite at a river in Northern Territory. Fishing guide Carol Gleeson watched as the hungry fresh water crocodile swallowed the lizard whole. The three-metre reptile noticed Ms Gleeson from a distance before it submerged into the water.

The four-month-old girl was airlifted to the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne where she remains in an induced coma. A man and a woman in their 20s, who were in the bedroom at the time of the crash, are in Geelong Hospital with minor injuries. Soaring farming costs and droughts have seen the population of rural NSW towns dwindle.

Researchers at Stanford University examined the reaction of secondary and primary school teachers in the United States to student race. They found that the teachers were more likely to view black pupils as troublemakers than those they thought were white. This may go someway towards explaining why black children are often disciplined more at schools compared to other pupils.

Peter Mutty was caught with two cartons of beer, one box of red wine and a box of white wine in his car on August 31 last year while driving home in Riyadh. The possession of alcohol is illegal in Saudi Arabia. He was jailed for six months and 75 lashes, but only received 28. Mutty has been unable to leave Saudi Arabia or work as he has been banned from travelling out of the country without any explanation as to why this is happening. The 57-year-old was sent to Thoqba prison in the Al Khobar Eastern Province on October 19 and was released on March 19.
Emmanuel Sithole was brutally attacked in Alexandra township near Johannesburg. He was left bleeding to death in a gutter because a medical centre just 300 feet away was closed for the day because the doctor who worked there was also a foreigner and feared becoming a victim of a xenophobic attack himself. His cause of death was later established as a direct stab wound to the heart and his identity established from a mobile phone.
Labour leader Harold Wilson lobbied the BBC to delay the show's repeat broadcast. He feared working class voters would stay at home and watch the show instead of voting. Mr Wilson was leader of the opposition and was seeking to oust Conservative Prime Minister Alec Douglas Home. He went to the home of BBC Director General Sir Hugh Greene and told him the show could cost him 20 seats.
Dale and Debra Krein of Rogue River, Oregon, filed a suit in 2012 against their neighbors and their giant Tibetan mastiffs. Jury ruled that the dogs should have their vocal chords removed within 60 days.

The character in question, Dr Franff, had a high-pitched laugh, a speech impediment and absurd habits like drinking from a surgical bag.
Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri died in fighting with government troops in Salahuddin province, north of Baghdad. He headed the Naqshbandi Order insurgent group, an important faction behind the rise of ISIS. He was ranked sixth on the US military's list of the 55 most-wanted Iraqis after offensive to overthrow Saddam.
Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS. It would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit. The system would have a range of 62 miles (100km) and could target things less than 0.4 inches (1cm) in size. The impact of the laser beam would create a force that reduced its velocity, causing it to fall into Earth’s atmosphere and burn up.
Almost a third of people aged 16-to-34 have deleted their accounts. Trend comes as increasing numbers of older users turn to the social network to stay in touch and share family pictures. Nearly 60 per cent of Britons aged over 55 now have a Facebook account.
Wonga lost £37.3million last year after being hit by new rules on payday lending. Chairman Andy Haste says the company might ditch its controversial brand in a bid to repair its reputation. Wonga's revenues fell by nearly £100million to a total of £217.2million.
Only 15 per cent of people at university now say they plan to vote Green, down from 28 per cent in February. The proportion of students who dislike Green leader Natalie Bennett has doubled to 24 per cent. Ms Bennett's profile has soared in recent months, buoyed by rising poll ratings and Green party membership in England passing 60,000 for the first time. But she has struggled in media performances, including a radio interview when she suffered a 'brain fade' while discussing housing policy.

The former leg spinner turned cricket commentating into an art form, earning him the title 'the Voice of Cricket'His sayings from the hundreds of Test and One Day cricket matches he commentated on were often what fans remembered from important moments. His trademark word, 'Marvellous...' will forever be linked to the cricket legend.

Alex Bellini, 36, will live atop an iceberg in Greenland starting next year. He will live inside a contained ball, with no means to escape for 12 months. The capsule will be 10ft (three metres) wide and could fit 10 people - but Mr Bellini will remove all of the seats apart from one, for himself. The aim of the stunt is to highlight how global warming will melt icebergs around the world and cause sea levels to rise.

Britain is likely to face a second election shortly after May 7 because of a knife-edge outcome, experts warn. The likelihood of another coalition lasting five years has been dismissed as miniscule by a leading academic. A second election swiftly after polling day is 'extremely likely', Professor Paul Whiteley said. He predicted a repeat of the disastrous Left-wing Lib-Lib pact of the 1970s.

Charlie Linville, 29, from Boise, Idaho, is using a specially designed metal foot outfitted with a climbing boot and another one with crampons in his quest to conquer the 8,850-meter (29,035-foot) summit next month. His quest last year was thwarted following the deaths of 16 Sherpa guides in April, the beginning of the climbing season, when an avalanche swept down. He plans to approach from the northern, Tibetan side, together with the Heroes Project's founder Tim Wayne Medvetz and an eight-member team.

It was supposed to be able to function for about 10 hours at levels of radiation which would be fatal to humans and cause ordinary electronic devices to malfunction. Kendall and Baylee Martin were born with very different skin tones thanks to a rare quirk of genetics. Their father, Curtis Martin, is half-Jamaican, while their mother Rebecca Horton, 28, is white. They were created when two eggs were fertilised by two sperm. Normally, you would expect both to inherit a mix of black and white genes and be born with a similar skin tone. But, in odds of a million to one, Baylee has inherited a set of genes for white skin and Kendall’s inherited some genes that code for black skin.

The small elephant left the tourism trade 'because she was too young [and] began to lose weight and could not carry the tourists any longer,' according to Elephant News' YouTube page.

Work at the Dome of the Rock was simply meant to replace carpet worn away by thousands of pilgrims at the gold-topped shrine, which overlooks old Jerusalem. But when the old carpet was lifted, it revealed previously undocumented ancient floor designs - which could point to where the Ark of the Covenant was buried 2,500 years ago. Scholars are furious they did not get the chance to document the designs before workmen began laying the new carpet.

Hernandez's fiancée, Shayanna Jenkins, sobbed and hugged the killer's mom in the Massachusetts court on Wednesday as the jury returned a guilty verdict. Just feet away across the aisle in the packed courtroom, sat her 23-year-old sister, Shaneah Jenkins, the girlfriend of victim Odin Lloyd who Hernandez executed with five bullets on June 17, 2013. The once-close sisters, who shared an apartment in their native Bristol, Connecticut, have not spoken since it became clear that Hernandez had a role in Lloyd's brutal death.
The Duke of Wellington's forces defeated and killed Tipu Sultan, the Tiger of Mysore, in 1799. Troops plundered the city and the palace, returning to Britain with gold, jewellery, arms, armour, clothing and even Tipu's grand throne. A collection of the historic artefacts from this exotic empire will go on sale at London auction house Bonhams, and experts expect them to fetch a total of around £1million.

He says he receives 20 new requests for help each week at his hemp store, Gnostic Hemporium, on the NSW Central Coast, north of Sydney. 'I've got people coming in all the time, who have everything from cancer to early onset Parkinson's,' the father of two said. The medicinal marijuana is broken down into the oil used by chronic pain sufferers and terminally ill.

UFO researcher Scott Waring says he has spotted an extra-terrestrial spacecraft in a 55-year-old photo from Nasa's Mercury Project. The image was taken as part of Project Mercury, which was the US' first mission to put men in space. Scientists say radical claims such as this are a simple case of pareidolia, which is the psychological response to seeing significant items in random places.

No Man's Land Fort is a Victorian sea fort in the middle of the Solent, just off the coast of the Isle of Wight. The fort has been transformed by AmaZing Venues to become a luxury hotel, and is set to open on April 23. Built between 1867 and 1880, it was ordered by then-Prime Minister Lord Palmerston to fend off the French Navy.
A California appeals court ruled yoga classes taught at Capri Elementary School in Encinitas, California, do not violate students' right to religious freedom. The district said the practice is taught in a secular way to promote strength, flexibility and balance. The First Amendment bans school-sponsored religious promotion and prayer.

Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index says the number of uninsured Americans is now at a record low. When tracking began in 2008 roughly 14per cent of citizens were uninsured, peaking at 18per cent in the third quarter of 2013. For the first three months of this year the rate dropped to 11.9per cent.

Scientists have found vast deep water gas hydrates in the Arctic that are reservoirs for abiotic methane. Abiotic methane is created by chemical reactions in the crust beneath the seafloor. It is 20 times more effective in trapping heat than carbon dioxide. The gas forms through a process called serpentinisation. This occurs when seawater reacts with hot mantle rocks exhumed along large faults.

Melon-headed whales washed onto two beaches at Hokota city, north-east of Tokyo. The whales, which are in fact a species of dolphin, were found washed up along a 6-mile (10km) stretch of the Pacific coast of Hokato, around 60 miles (100km) north of Tokyo, last week. Officials are still investigating the cause of the strandings but they triggered rumours on social media of an impending earthquake.
Average Australian sheds equivalent of a 50 gram packet of chips every week in dry skin, feeding an army of dust mites into our couches and beds. Dust mites are the number one cause of allergies in Australian homes and may be the reason why you have a runny nose or watery eyes. The odd shaped critters increase two to three fold during late autumn to winter leading thousands of Australians to suffer from common colds / flu.

University of Manchester researchers have revealed an HD dark matter map. It shows clumps of mystery particles across 0.4 per cent of the sky. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 per cent over five years. The map should allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe.

Replica of the warship that carried France's Marquis de Lafayette to help American colonists in their war of independence sets sail for the United States on Saturday. Lafayette crossed the Atlantic on the original Hermione in 1780 to tell his friend George Washington, commander of the American insurgents against British imperial rule, that France was sending a strong military force to help them. The new Hermione has been under construction since 1997 and cost 25 million euros ($27 million) to build.
Footage appears to show Arsenal fans singing a homophobic chant about Ashley Cole. The video was apparently filmed at the Green Man pub in Wembley ahead of Arsenal's FA Cup semi-final win over Reading. Metropolitan police are assessing the footage and are in the process of contacting relevant parties.
Around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) are classified as refugees in India's only Muslim-majority state of Jammu. They are unable to own property or vote in state elections - meaning three generations are caught in abject poverty.
Biologists at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in Israel studied the cephlopods movement. They found that the orientation of the creature's body and the crawling direction are controlled independently in the brain. The findings may help scientists develop new ways for soft robots to move around.
Islamic extremists drove cars to a mosque in remote village of Kwajafa in Borno state. They told locals they were there to teach Islam before opening fire on a crowd. The jihadis opened fire using handguns and assault rifles before setting fire to nearby houses. Attack came as new pictures showed how teenagers caught up in previous slaughters are being encouraged draw pictures of the attacks as part of their therapy.

When she became pregnant with her second child, less than two years later, she was reassured the same mistakes would not be repeated. When Patrick was delivered at the same hospital, the same errors were made. Ms McKay, from Leyland, near Preston, has been awarded £13 million in compensation.

Alex aid that he had'missed out on a lot' when he was clocking in at 354lbs.
If the brain is tired, it affects the memory even for those without dementia. Getting a good night's sleep can be especially difficult for those with dementia, especially those with Alzheimer's disease who may experience changes to their sleeping patterns. It is a common misconception that we need less sleep as we get older - in fact we need just as much, the problem is that older people find it harder to reach a deeper sleep.
Vet Nick Fisher, 31, from Leintwardine, Shropshire, said his dog Twiglet was left behaving strangely after eating the drugs he found at a bus stop while on a walk near their home last Monday. The four-year-old hound seemed to think he was being chased and had dilated pupils and bloodshot eyes. After 45 minutes of drooling at the mouth uncontrollably, shaking and walking into walls he seems to be back to normal.

Police have ruled the tragedy an accident, although they are still investigating the circumstances of the Chinese woman’s death.

Horses, ponies and donkeys are being abandoned in record numbers across the country. Many are left to fend for themselves or tied up on busy roadsides in the hope that someone will rescue them. The RSPCA alone took in 1,500 horses last year, many of them former family pets.

Sarah, 23, was devastated to find out the man she's known as her father for 23 years is not her real father. Her mother told her last year that Phil, who raised her, may not be related to her. Sarah agreed to appear on the Jeremy Kyle Show to undergo a DNA test to discover the truth.
Hedione - derived from the Greek word 'hedone', for fun, pleasure, lust - has a fresh jasmine-magnolia scent. Christian Dior fragrance, Eau Savage, was the first to use it in 1966, and it has since found its way into other fragrances such as Chamade by Guerlain, CKOne, Paco by Paco Rabane and Chanel no. 19. Scientists analysed brain activity when a person smelled Hedione to find out how it changed their emotions and behaviour. They then compared the results with the effects caused by a common floral fragrance known as phenylethyl alcohol.

The couple took photos at each stage of their respective pregnancies, recording when their first child, a son Jax, was born followed by their daughter Ero, a year later.

John Helinski, 62, spent three years living in a cardboard box on the streets of Tampa Bay. He then tried to apply for a place at a homeless shelter, but all of his ID had been stolen. Case manager Charles Inman and Tampa Bay police officer Dan McDonald were determined to find out more about his background. They found an old, forgotten bank account with enough social security benefits in it to buy a new house.

The restaurant reopened about 4 p.m. Thursday.
Naomi Jacobs was 32 when she woke up one morning having lost her memory of the past 17 years of her life. She had Transient Global Amnesia, a form of memory loss brought on by stress. The condition caused the 'episodic' part of her memory to shut down, meaning she lost all her emotional memories.

Her weight dropped to 80lbs, and she had to postpone her wedding as she spent more and more time in hospitals.
