A friend of the photographer insisted it was 'not photoshopped' and that paranormal forces could be at work. A kestrel and a barn owl repeatedly lunged at each other while trying to gain mastery of the box so they could lay eggs and rear their young in safety. The fight was captured on video by wildlife photographer Robert Fuller, using a camera he set up inside a 13ft-high elm tree stump in his garden in North Yorkshire.

Photos taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty show Beijing's famous landmarks with barely any visitors. Black and white photos show locals and foreigners posing at the Temple of Heaven, standing next to giant statues at the Western Qing Tombs and riding on boats at the Summer Palace. Some of the subjects in the photographs offer wide smiles, while others pose with blank expressions.
Mitchell Moffit and Greg Brown, from Toronto, present an online science show. They discuss how being the first, middle, youngest, or an only child affects us. First-born children are expected to be higher academic achievers and more ambitious. Middle-borns tend to be more co-operative and are more likely to be social butterflies. Only children are more creative and creative, and have a stronger sense of security and confidence.
Rodrigo de Freitas lake is set to host rowing and canoeing events during next year's Games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. More than 37 tons of fish have been collected, according to Rio's waste management company, but there is still an overwhelming stench, sparking complaints from neighbours and passers-by. Rubbish collectors will continue to rake the decomposing fish off the water's surface until mass dying subsides.
Pregnant women with hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) are more likely to have children with language and speech delays, and attention disorders, a study claims. About 10,000 women a year in the UK are affected by the debilitating condition, which causes constant vomiting, crippling weakness and dehydration.

Surveys find that men in U.S. special operations forces do not believe women can meet the physical and mental demands of their commando jobs. They fear the Pentagon will lower standards to integrate women into their elite units. Studies that surveyed personnel found'major misconceptions' about whether women should be brought into the male-only jobs.
Esa’s Rosetta spacecraft has captured stunning images of a dust jet erupting from comet 67P Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Jet may have been caused by a wave of heat reaching ice trapped under the surface, causing an explosion of material. But it is unusual, because so far such activity has only been spotted on the day-side of the comet - not the night.

More than 730,285 Reddit users have pressed The Button since the California firm launched its r/thebutton thread on April Fool's Day. Only people who registered on the site before this date are eligible to click The Button. When they do they are awarded a colour, known as a 'flair'This colour represents the time period at which they clicked The Button, ranging from zero to 60 seconds.

Babies given antibiotics in first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers. Finnish researchers compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year old with records on antibiotic prescription. By two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese.
Around 50 obese children at Jianxin Primary School, in eastern China, are being put through their paces by instructors every day after school to help them lose weight. Teachers set up the lessons after a survey revealed 5 per cent of the school's 800 pupils were obese, including one 11-year-old who weighs 180lbs. The lessons are named after a Dreamworks film of the same name in which an overweight panda becomes a kung fu master.

A 'blob' of warm water 2,000 miles across is sitting in the Pacific Ocean. Since last June it has extended from Alaska to Mexico. It has been present since 2013 and causing fish to seek shelter elsewhere. And a new University of Washington study says it could be responsible for droughts. California's drought is one of the worst on record, while the East coast of the US has seen unusually cold temperatures.

Kushner testified that the 2007 charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence.

He was executed by lethal injection at 10.15pm on Tuesday at the Eastern Reception, Diagnostic and Correctional Center in Bonne Terre, Missouri. His fate was sealed after the U.S. Supreme Court turned down several appeals, including one claiming Cole was mentally ill and unfit for execution.

Queensland Health says there is an insufficient supply of whooping cough vaccine in Australia, according to ABC News. Medical professionals insist the resource shortage will not affect the immunisation programs for babies, children and pregnant women. It comes less than a month after the death of 32-day-old Riley Hughes who died after contracting the disease. His parents Catherine and Greg are urging adults to vaccinate themselves and their children to prevent more infant deaths from the terrible disease.

Palaeontologists say the four feet (1.2 metres) tall bird is one of the most complete skeletons of a 'terror bird' - a group of flightless prehistoric meat-eating birds. The South American bird has been named Llallawavis scagliai - meaning Scaglia's Magnificent Bird. It was so well preserved that scientists have been able to study part of the bird's auditory system and its trachae. They say that while it had a terrifying apperance, its hearing was probably below average compared to birds living today.
Heart patients who expressed gratitude for the positive things in their life had better mental and physical health, a study found. The study involved men and women who had been diagnosed with Stage B heart failure. The 186 patients were assessed for their levels of gratitude using standard psychological tests.
The I'm Up Alarm can be set to go off the night before and will then only turn off by scanning a QR code on a mug or magnet that can be kept in another room. The app uses a Quick Response code, or QR code, which is a form of barcode that the cameras of mobile phones are able to detect. It will be available on Apple and Android phones and a version for Windows phones is being developed.

Stroke patients with damage in the sagittal stratum in the right hemisphere of the brain were far poorer at detecting sarcasm when listening to sentences, according to the new research. Stroke survivors often suffer damage to this area of their brain and struggle to recognise when family and friends are being sarcastic.

'Kick and kill' strategy aims to eradicate the virus, by stimulating the immune system - the body's natural defence mechanism - with a vaccine. Could flush out dormant HIV hiding in white blood cells with a chemical 'kick', allowing a boosted immune system to identify and kill the cells. The Black Book of Carmarthen is the earliest surviving medieval manuscript written solely in Welsh. It contains some of the earliest references to Arthur and Merlin. Now, researchers have found a series of hidden faces and message in it. Using a combination of ultraviolet light and photo editing software, the 16th century owner's penchant for erasure has been reversed.

Owner of the Bunny Baker Cafe in Manila etches customised caricatures into coffee froth. Zach Yonzon runs the cafe with his wife and uses steamed milk and froth as the canvas. He claims that his art can be done with almost any type of coffee drink and that the final product will depend on the thickness of the beverage.

Scientists from the University of Wollongong are designing ultra-durable condoms they claim could feel even better than nothing at all. The contraceptive is made with hydrogel, a strong and flexible solid which can be made to feel and act like human tissue. The groundbreaking design will eventually offer functions like self-lubrication, topical drug delivery, and even electric conductivity.

Officials from 215 local, state and federal law-enforcement agencies seized hoards of weapons, drugs and cash at the addresses. At least 913 have already been charged with a range of crimes including rape, murder and sexual assault. Jackson's family and friends have been desperately trying to raise $80,000 needed to pay the hospital upfront by Tuesday night, so that he can undergo the operation on Wednesday morning. On Monday morning they reached the target on their GoFundMe page, but Jackson's mother says the family needs an additional $45,000 to cover chemotherapy and other hospital fees.

Storm chaser Dan Robinson believes 'looped lightning' is simply a trick of perspective, based on where a viewer is stood. Upwards lightning is very rare - estimates suggest less than 1% of lightning travels in an ‘upwards’ direction.
Carlos Toro, 66, worked as a mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel in the 1980s. He fled Colombia fearing for his life when a confrontation with his boss caused him to flee. Toro came to the United States and began working for the DEA as an informant. He became one of the DEA's most important assets and helped carry out undercover stings around the world. He wasn't paid for work, but was told he would be rewarded with US citizenship. He is now technically living in the US illegally after declining health forced him to retire.

Caitlin Kellie-Jones was diagnosed with Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE)HIE is a type of brain damage that occurs when the brain does not receive enough oxygen. To control the condition Caitlin was placed in a special cooling wrap within 40 minutes of her birth. It allows the brain to cool down and minimises the damage from the lack of oxygen. Caitlin, now ten months old, recovered from HIE and is able to feed and play.

In 1992, a Drug Enforcement Agency program monitored every telephone call made from the United States to one of the 116 countries on their watch list for drug trafficking, including almost every country in both North and South America. The program allowed agents to monitor calls the ruled out the possibility of foreign ties to the 1995 bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building by American Timothy McVeigh. This is the oldest known example of the American government authorizing this level of tracking on unknowing citizens of the country.

The 18-carat gold Irish Freedom Box was presented to Lord Uxbridge in 1828 by Trinity College Dublin when he served as Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. It was sold by Bonhams to a private collector for more than £100,900. The box is about three-and-a-half inches long and weighs just six ounces.

But the stamp duty alone, paid on top of the price of the home, is enough for the Treasury to pay the annual salary of 330 nurses. Property has now been bought by an offshore company for £51,191,950, according to Land Registry figures.

Inside Abbey Road is a new web app that takes users on an interactive, immersive and hugely detailed virtual tour of the inner workings of Abbey Road studios. More than 500,000 people knock on doors of studios every year only to be told it is closed to the public. The studios hosted the world's first live global broadcast - from none other than The Beatles - as well as playing a role in the invention of stereo by EMI engineer Alan Blumlein.

Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust teams have seen number of encounters increase by 68 per cent over the past 12 years. The dolphins come to the Hebrides in spring to take advantage of seasonal food stocks, travelling in large groups and sometimes forming ‘super-pods’ of thousands of individuals. The species, which are smaller than the area’s resident bottlenose dolphins, often approach boats and play in the wake.

Researchers at the Technical University of Braunschweig, Germany, have shown that passive smoking affects plants too. Peppermint plants can take up high concentrations of nicotine from contaminated soil and plumes of smoke. The finding may explain why some spices, herbal teas and medicinal plants have high concentrations despite none being allowed in insecticides.

PETA spokesperson Pamela Anderson joined controversial Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio on Wednesday to promote the benefits of a vegetarian diet for prison inmates. Arpaio says cutting meat from the meals served to the more than 8,000 inmates has saved an estimated $200,000 per year. Anderson, a longtime vegan and a spokeswoman for the animal rights group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said she hopes the meal initiative stands as a model for prisons and jails across the country.
The rare mammal has been making waves at the Taiji Whale Museum in southern Japan. While bottlenose dolphins are typically grey, the mammal is completely white - apart from the quirky tendency to turn pink when it's feeling angry, sad or even embarrassed. The rare specimen is believed to be only the second one ever put on display in an aquarium after it was purchased from fishermen last year.

Alarmed by a rash of explosions caused by amateur hash production, Colorado and Washington lawmakers are considering limits on making the marijuana concentrate at home. The proposals came after an increase in home fires and blasts linked to homemade hash oil. In Colorado, at least 30 people were injured last year in 32 butane explosions involving hash oil — nearly three times the number reported throughout 2013.

Lucy, the oldest and most complete fossil of an early human ever found, still has a few secrets to reveal. A new look at the ancient hominin's skeleton suggests one of the bones may belong to a baboon. The skeleton belongs to a species called Australopithecus afarensis and is 40 per cent complete.
The Modular Robotic Vehicle, or MRV, was developed at NASA's Johnson Space Center to show off the technologies that could let man move across other planets. The buggy has no mechanical linkages to the propulsion, steering, or brake actuators, the driver relies completely on electrical signals and then transmitted by wires to the vehicle's motors.

Velella velella are not technically jellyfish, but they are closely related to them and are similar to the Man-O-War. They have a small sail on top of their bodies, which means they are easily blown to shore during strong winds this time of year.
Freddo Frog has shrunk from 15g to 12g. Cadbury is cutting the size of its beloved Freddo Frogs by 20 per cent. The miniature chocolate amphibians weighed a plump 20g two years ago - before they dropped to 15g. The shrinking of one of Australia's most popular children’s chocolates was in fact spotted by a shop owner who stocks the treats.
Ground-Based Air Defense Directed Energy On-the-Move program, commonly referred to as GBAD, allows controllers to simply drive the weapon to a target. System will be able to spot and track drones, then shoot them out of the sky using a 30kw laser. System is being designed for use on light tactical vehicles such as the Humvee and Joint Light Tactical Vehicle.

Landmarks Preservation Commission was established by New York City Mayor Robert Wagner on April 19, 1965. The law was upheld by the Supreme Court in 1978 following a campaign led by Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis to save another iconic railroad station, Grand Central. The commission was given a mandate to preserve buildings and places of cultural, architectural and historical significance.

A spokesman for TWC questioned the reports saying that the company has been working productively with both the DOJ and the Federal Communications Commission. The merger has been under extreme scrutiny since it was announced last February.

Zane Gbangbola died at home – in the middle of the night – after being poisoned by gas which authorities claimed was from a faulty pump at his house. For months after his death, police and other official agencies ruled out fears that the deadly fumes had come from a nearby landfill site. Instead, they insisted carbon monoxide from faulty pump hired by his family had caused his death. But damning new evidence proves the authorities knew for 14 months that hydrogen cyanide gas capable of killing Zane had leaked into the family's home.
Swedish scientists analysed more than 10,000 families with children aged two to 14 who did not have the condition. They looked at whether there was any family conflict, a change of family structure, interventions from social services or unemployment. Subsequently, 58 children were diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. Researchers found many were among those badly affected by events in their formative years.
It shows 'ribbons' of sand and patterned stripes known as linear dunes in the Erg Chech, a desolate sand sea in southwestern Algeria - but the exact cause of these longitudinal structures is not known. Linear dunes are straight ridges of sand that have been known to measure as long as 99 miles (160km)The colours were caused as rays of sunlight hit the sand and were reflected off.
Soldiers uncovered a trapdoor leading to a suspected drugs tunnel hidden inside a wooden wardrobe in Tijuana, Mexico. The 66ft deep route was wired with lights, ventilation and what appears to be a cart system by the gang of drugs runners. The route had not yet reached U.S. soil, but officials believe it would have surfaced a short distance from the border.

The chef’s ex-boyfriend had gone round to her home to collect his belongings after 18-month relationship. But when Mr Judson bent down to pick up something, she jumped on his back and wrapped iPod lead around his neck. She then armed herself with a large carving knife and stabbed at him several times with the blade. Was arrested and charged with attempting to inflict grievous bodily harm with intent to cause serious injury. But she was cleared of this after her plea of guilty to an alternative offence of affray was accepted.

The suicides of five young sailors who served on the same base over two years has unearthed a shocking culture of ice taking, binge drinking, bullying and depression within the Australian Navy. The sailors were stationed or had been stationed at the West Australian port of HMAS Stirling off the coast of Rockingham, south of Perth. Their families did not learn of their previous attempts to take their own lives and their drug use until after their deaths.

He was convicted in Houston and served time in Louisana and Georgia before his 2012 release which was commuted because of good behavior. The four sisters at the centre of Australia's largest abduction case have come through the ordeal as happy and well-adjusted children. Despite being embroiled in the very public and traumatic feud where the Vinceni girls were dragged kicking and screaming from their mother's home in the middle of the night to go back to live with their father in 2012, the girls have established healthy and happy lives in Italy and speak to their mum every night. 60 Minutes reporter Tara Brown interviewed the two eldest girls, Emily and Claire, who she described as elegant, gracious, reserved and studious, at their home near Florence.

She ran out of food and began to suffer from malnutrition along with her baby. She stopped breastfeeding after two months because she was so undernourished and switched to baby formula. Avoca Beach in the Central Coast, about 95kms north of Sydney, resembled something from a horror film on Tuesday. Sylvia Freedman filmed the disturbing scene that stretched out more than 15 metres from the top of the beach pathway to beyond the water's edge. Her videos show a grotesque, yellow, jelly like substance moving around as the wind blows it up and over surrounding scrubland. 'Whenever the wind blew, the foam just felt like you were in a snow globe,' she said.

Reading scientists say chewing gum helps you forget a song. In a study people were less likely to think about it when chewing, and they were a third less likely when chewing. The results suggests same technique could stop other intrusive thoughts. The study was carried out by scientists at the University of Reading.

Will Hatton has made a career out of travelling the globe as The Broke Backpacker. The 26-year-old British backpacker has only once tried to conform to a regular nine-to-five desk job at a travel agency - an endeavour that failed within six months. He makes money through any random odd job he can find in foreign lands and spends only $100 each week on all of his expenses. He has visited nearly 50 countries over the last seven years and aims to reach 100 by the time he turns 30.

Archaeologists at Boston University and the University of Bath believe this would have meant they lost out when modern humans arrived from Africa. Without fire, a group of Neanderthals would have had less energy - the equivalent of 12 reindeer a year - than if they did. It is more likely that they disappeared 40,000 years ago because of interbreeding and assimilation with our early modern human ancestors, scientists believe.

Norway will switch off its FM transmitters on January 11, 2017. It will be the first country in the world to switch off FM radio signals in favour of digital. SwiftKey analysed more than one billion sets of emoji data, covering 800 emoji across 60 categories. The languages studied include English, including US, UK and Australian, Spanish, Vietnamese, French, Malaysian, Arabic, German, Turkish and French, Portuguese, Italian and Russian. Happy faces, including winks, kisses, smiles and grins were the most popular across all regions, making up 45 per cent of all the messages studied. Sad faces were in second place followed by hearts, which includes all colours of hearts and the broken heart emoji. Hand gestures such as thumbs up, clapping hands and the peace were in fourth followed by romantic emoji, such as the lipstick kiss mark, love letter and couple kissing.

Humpback whale populations are to be declassified as 'endangered' following successful conservation programme. At one stage the worldwide population dropped to just a few thousand due to over-fishing and hunting, but it has now recovered to 90,000. Noaa Fisheries in Maryland says the humpback whale is no longer endangered. They want to break up global population into 14 sub-populations. Ten of these will be deemed 'not at risk', two 'threatened' and two still ‘endangered’
Scientists in Belgium say all sweet potatoes contain 'foreign DNA'Agrobacterium bacteria in the crop exchanges genes between species. This makes sweet potatoes a 'natural genetically modified organism'And humans have been eating it for thousands of years.

Samantha Rawcliffe, 40, from Morecambe, lost control of her body and crashed her car last May. She blamed her uncontrollable shaking in the aftermath of the accident on her shock. Tests revealed she was suffering functional neurological disorder - an umbrella term for a wide variety of neurological symptoms that doctors cannot explain. The condition can be as debilitating as Parkinson's disease and MS and may share many common symptoms.

He denied lying to his boss about how many he had taken and kept them on his device until August 2013.
University of Illinois scientists have created the first 3D simulation of merging black holes in a disk. It shows what happens when two supermassive black holes collide. Material swirls around the objects in a quasar and jets fire out from the poles in the merger. It comes after two black holes were found to be seven years from merging.
Observers heard her scream 'F***', and other obscenities when she ran out of the room and down the hall. Richards, 50, was arrested last week and charged with public intoxication, trespassing, resisting an officer and battery on a police officer.
The UCO Stormproof Matches are made using an incredibly tough coating that smoulders no matter what happens to them and will start burning again once it comes into contact with oxygen. The matches have to go through rigorous testing to make sure they keep alight in even the most difficult situations. They include 25 matches in a completely waterproof case with and three strike pads.

The usually garrulous and broad-smiling Clinton stared straight ahead, continued walking alongside her Secret Service and local police escorts, and said nothing. Yom Hazikaron - or Memorial Day - is held the day before Israel's independence day. Remembrance ceremonies began at sunset on Tuesday and continue until nightfall on Wednesday. Israel remembers 23,320 fallen since 1860 in fighting for the national cause.
Noise-induced hearing loss is one of the most common work-related illnesses. Scientists at the University of Southern California believe they have made a breakthrough in their understanding of the condition. They have identified a gene, named Nox3, found in the inner ear, that is crucial in determining how vulnerable a person is to developing hearing loss.
Palaeontologists say male stegosaurus could have used them to show off their prowess in much the same way as peacocks do today. It raises the prospect that the dinosaurs used its giant bony protrusions to attract a mate.

Papyrus was found in Oxyrhynchus, Egypt, and contains a medical'recipe' for treating a hangover. The text recommends stringing the leaves of a shrub called Alexandrian chamaedaphne together and possibly wearing it around the neck. While the text recommends this as a way of relieving headaches brought on by alcohol, it is not known if it had any effect.

UK passengers faced more holiday chaos than during same period last year, according to analysis from flight data specialist EUclaim. There have so far been 5,080 flight cancellations, compared to 4,239 cancellations during the same period in 2014. Number of delays also increased to 2,427 from 2,260 in 2014, with low-cost carrier Monarch experiencing a 30% increase in delays.

The James Webb Space Telescope will be 100 times more potent than Hubble, and will be able to see back to 200 million years after the Big Bang. The space telescope will weigh 6.4 tons and will carry four instruments, including cameras and spectrometers that can capture extremely faint signals. The project has drawn scrutiny from lawmakers for its ballooning costs - now at about $8.8 billion.

Traditionally known as a 'naatsit', the underwear is adorned with beads and would have been sewn together by a woman using strips of seal pelt. It is currently on display at the National Museum of Denmark in Copenhagen as part of its animal-skin clothing collection. It was obtained during an expedition to the Ammassalik settlement in Greenland in 1892 by Captain C. Ryder. When leaving a settlement, the female wearer would have worn this naastit under trousers.

Warning comes after a survey found almost half of dog owners did not know that ticks can transmit deadly diseases to both humans and other dogs. Lyme disease, a potentially fatal illness caught from tick bites, affects their pets as well as themselves.

Oskar Groening is being tried on 300,000 counts of accessory to murder at Lueneburg state court in Germany. He was on duty when 450,000 Hungarian Jews were brought to Auschwitz-Birkenau complex in Nazi-occupied Poland and most immediately gassed to death. Auschwitz survivors describe their arrival as chaotic, with Nazi guards yelling orders, dogs barking and families being ripped apart. But Groening, 93, said 'it was very orderly and not as strenuous' on the ramp at Birkenau.

The 19th-century canal was once a major transportation route, but it's now so polluted with industrial and sewer discharges that it must, by law, be cleaned up. A baby whale once got lost in the canal in 2007 and died within two days.

Chinese scientists have admitted to changing the genes of human embryos for the first time in history. The team tried to tweak the gene responsible for β-thalassaemia, a potentially deadly blood disorder, using a germ line editing technique known as CRISPR/Cas9. Some scientists have reacted with horror at the idea, for fear it could be misused to allow parents to'select' the genes they will pass on to their grandchildren.

Tianwen Chen, 65, and his wife Gairen Guo, 60, adopted 40 disabled children over the past 26 years. The couple found their first child in a box on the side of the road in 1989 and carried her home. They gradually took more and more disabled children into their two-bedroom home in rural Shanxi province, central China. Eventually, nearly 20 children were sleeping on the floor in their 20 square metre farmhouse. Sadly, nine of the children died and another 12 were adopted by other families.

Jackson Byrnes, 18, was told he had a stage four brain tumour that was too deep and aggressive to be safely operated on. Renowned neurosurgeon Dr Charlie Teo was the only surgeon in Australia willing to perform the risky operation that will likely see the Casino teenager paralysed. His family refused to accept the dismal diagnosis and took matters into their own hands and found Dr Teo, who said he would perform the operation if the family understood the risks. The 18-year-old underwent a risky operation to remove the tumour on his brain on Wednesday.

Stephanie Scott was remembered as a 'beautiful friend' who brought laughter to her loved ones, in a touching funeral service on Wednesday. Hundreds of people gathered at Eat Your Greens, just outside Eugowra in NSW's central west, to pay their respects to the beloved teacher who was allegedly murdered on Easter Sunday, just days before her wedding. Among the mourners were her fiance and partner of five years Aaron Leeson-Woolley, who was dressed in a black bow tie with a yellow flower pinned to his shirt, her mother Merrilyn, father Robert, and her siblings. Her sister, Kim, shared humorous childhood memories of Ms Scott with the crowd and painted a picture of someone with a strong sense of who she was.

Swazi gold is grown in the tiny South African sovereign state of Swaziland, where the climate and nutrient-rich soil is perfect for growing marijuana. Farmers have developed the potent strain through cross-pollination and can now yield double the crop they once could annually. Swazi gold that stays in South Africa is now commonly mixed with heroin to make a highly addictive new cocktail known as nyope. Nyope contains a heroin concentration of around ten per cent, and often 'fillers' including rat poison and crushed HIV tablets.
Phoebe Jo Chapman, 42, turned herself in to police on Tuesday morning and was booked on three counts of sexual assault - one count for each victim. Police say the charges stem from three separate encounters with different boys at Lowndes High School in Valdosta, Georgia. Chapman resigned from the school as the investigation got underway.

Pilots have reported 167 cases of toxic cabin fumes or smoke in only four months. Twelve of the cases resulted in the pilots requesting a priority landing, one flight was diverted and on two flights the pilots made an emergency Mayday call. Figures have re-opened argument about whether prolonged exposure to the air in planes is safe.
Massey Shaw was requisitioned from the London Fire Brigade in 1940 and transported to Dunkirk to help with the evacuation of Allied troops in the face of the Nazi advance. After carrying 600 soldiers back to Britain, the boat returned to London where it helped to save St Paul's Cathedral and other buildings damaged in the Blitz. The boat is still capable of pumping out 3,000 gallons of water every minute, the same as four fire engines.

He admitted two counts of fraud by lying to Abbey National about the profitability of his business to secure the £847,000 loan in March 2007. He also admitted five charges of deception after he used his position to inflate the salaries of five of his clients and help them obtain mortgages totalling £686,000.

Biologists have studied the healing process at a molecular level using electron microscopes to examine skin as it repairs itself. They found skin cells appear to attach to each other using tiny tubes that then pull them together so they interlock like a zip. The researchers hope their findings could help in the development of new treatments for wounds that could speed up this process.

Stewart Brand, president of the Long Now Foundation and editor of the Whole Earth Catalogue, believes the focus on mass extinctions may actually be harmful. He argues it is highly unlikely that the planet is facing a sixth mass extinction as many threatened species are recovering. The rate of discovery of new species is currently outstripping the loss of species to extinction.

Kate Roberts noticed her son Miles had a slightly different shaped head when he was born. At three months, he was diagnosed with brachycephaly, also known as 'flat head syndrome'This is when the back of the head becomes flattened, causing the head to widen and the front of the skull to bulge out. Doctors believe it is caused by babies sleeping on their back, and as it is not medically dangerous, the NHS does not pay for treatment.

Asian-American rock band The. Slants, who say they chose their name as a way to reclaim a term. usually considered a racial slur, cannot trademark the name because it is disparaging, a U.S. appeals court ruled on Monday. The Portland, Oregon-based band, which plays a kind of. grunge music it calls Chinatown Dance Rock, applied for. trademarks in 2010 and 2011, and was rejected both times on the. grounds the name disparaged Asians. The ruling could have implications for the high-profile fight over whether the National Football League's Washington. Redskins should lose its trademarks.

Albert Davison made a fortune by landing a series of six-figure bets on his own horses. When he died, aged 73, he owned a seven-bedroom country estate in Surrey which had been valued at £4.25million. He and his second wife Penny Ann Davison, 59, fought a bitter battle through the divorce courts for four years. A judge found that Mr Davison had squandered millions through 'wasteful expenditure' and 'bad decision making'

Video sparked fierce debate on the use of deadly force with some accusing him of misconduct and others labeling the cop a hero. Valencia remained in hospital for two days before being booked into jail.
Keepers at the Columbus Zoo say ten-year-old Irisa had mated before but never conceived. This spring it was found the female cat was pregnant - with triplets. But Irisa failed to show any maternal care so her offspring are currently being hand-reared in an incubator.
Hillary Clinton's newborn presidential campaign is reeling from new financial links between her family foundation and companies that benefited from her stewardship of the U.S. State Department. In one case a foundation run by the chairman of Uranium One, a nuclear energy company tied to Russia, gave the Clintons' family philanthropy millions while Hillary's State Department gave its stamp of approval to the company's purchase of US uranium. The Russian state atomic agency Rosatom purchased a majority stake in the Vancouver-based company in a years-long process that unfolded from 2009 to 2013 – the same years Mrs. Clinton was America's secretary of state.

The video was viewed around three million times and now two years on the young girl has returned to update the world on her progress.
Brendan Cordina drove 3500 kilometres in four days to find his grandfather's medals. The medals belonged to Captain Jack Slade, a flight lieutenant in World War II. Medals include an Airforce Cross, War Medal 39-45 Star, a Queen Elizabeth II Coronation Medal and others. Mr Cordina was refused the medals and told that they 'were more important to the museum'The museum instead offered to send him replicas to which he was outraged.

Unidentified victim will speak out in tonight's episode of Crimewatch. She tells reporters she is too scared to sleep for fear of reliving the ordeal in her dreams. West Yorkshire Police are treating the crime as a rape and attempted murder.
A federal court of appeals threw out the career home run leader's obstruction of justice conviction on Wednesday, ruling 10-1 that his meandering answer before a grand jury in 2003 was not material to the government's investigation into illegal steroids distribution. 'Today's news is something that I have long hoped for,' Bonds said in a statement. He was convicted of the obstruction charge in 2011, and a three-judge panel of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously upheld the conviction in 2013. The appellate judges based their decision on legal issues involving witness testimony, not the underlying facts.
Rebels bikie gang president Alex Vella has been banned from Australia for life. Three Federal Court judges ruled that Vella, 61, be prohibited from returning after the government cancelled the Rebels president's visa while he was overseas in his native Malta last year. The decision strands Vella in Malta, leaving behind in Australia 24 close family members including a wife, sons and an elderly mother, all of whom are Australian citizens. Vella is the longtime boss of the Rebels, which police say are involved in drug dealing, money laundering, serious assaults, kidnapping, extortion, firearms offences and intimidating court witnesses.
Yamini Karanam, 26, was diagnosed with a pineal tumour in her brain after noticing she was struggling to understand things she had read, and felt lost in conversations. Surgeons operating on the 26-year-old discovered the growth was in fact a teratoma - a growth containing bone, hair and teeth.
Google launched a new U.S. wireless service today that switches between Wi-Fi and cellular networks. The service, called 'Project Fi,' debuted today, about two months after Google revealed its plans to expand its ever-growing empire into providing wireless connections for smartphones. Google is selling the basic phone service for $20 a month and will only charge customers for the amount of cellular data that they use each month, instead of a flat rate. Project Fi will work only on the company's Nexus 6 phones and only in the US.

The Duke University study compared its results to the most severe emissions scenarios outlined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)It claims that natural variability in surface temperatures over the course of a decade can account for increases and dips in warming rates. But it adds that these so-called 'climate wiggles' could also, in the future, cause our planet to warm up much faster than anticipated. The study says that variability is caused by interactions between the ocean and atmosphere, and other natural factors.
Three men arrested on suspicion of murder of missing chef Claudia Lawrence have been released on bail. The three men, who are in their 50s are all from the York area, are all in their 60s. The trio were questioned over night by police investigating the chef's disappearance. Ms Lawrence was 35 when she vanished on March 18, 2009. Her father, Peter, reported her missing after she failed to turn up to work.
A pilot has blamed one of his passengers for coughing 'incessantly' into his headset during a short flight in the Northern Territory which caused him to forget to put the landing gear down, an air crash report has found. The Australian Air Transport Safety Bureau released its report on Wednesday into the 'wheels up landing' on December 12, 2014 at Jabiru Airport, southeast of Darwin. The pilot was flying a six-seat Cessna 310 aircraft, registered VH-TBE, with two adults and three children on board when he became distracted by one of the passengers. Despite this, the report also found the pilot was'relatively new to the C-310' and unfamiliar with the plane equipment.
Record number of rapes and other sex crimes were logged by police last year, figures show. Number of rapes at knifepoint were up by 31 per cent to 311 attacks and there were 53,559 other sexual offences.
Marissa Holcomb, who is five months pregnant with her fourth child, was fired from Popeyes in Channelview, Texas, on March 31. She was held at gunpoint by a man armed with a handgun and his face concealed with a red beanie. The robber managed to get $400 from the till, which Popeyes said was too much money to have kept in the register. Her bosses said it was against policy to have such an amount in the till and gave her an ultimatum - pay it back or lose her job. She refused to pay back the money and was fired less than two days after the incident. Popeyes have now offered her job back and have offered her $2,000 in backpay.
Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum, in Oświęcim, Poland, has had more than 250,000 visitors so far this year. This is a rise of more than 40 per cent compared with the same period last year, which itself hit a record with 1.5 million visitors. The memorial site has urged potential visitors to book their visits online ahead of time to ensure entry.

Three men and a woman punched and kicked him 20 times in the head and across his body. Mr Blanks was taunted by the group before snatching the hat from his head. His family say it will take him a long time to recover and he has been left with deep scars.
Just The Flight have researched city nicknames all over the world to produce a handy infographic. Some nicknames refer to the ancient heritage of the city, some to the industry found in the city and others to the environment. Las Vegas is known as Sin City now for it's gambling and temptation - but the nickname dates back to a building used by prostitutes. Amsterdam in the Netherlands is known for its great number of canals, and so even if you didn't know, you could understand why it is called 'The Venice Of The North'

Supermarket giant announced a record annual loss of £6.38billion yesterday. Loss is largest ever declared by a British retailer and reflects shift in shopping habits away from big supermarkets towards smaller budget stores. Britain’s biggest retailer made a profit of £1.4billion on sales through the tills across the world in the year to the end of February.

Mobile X-ray scanner, heralded as the world’s first ‘airplane scanner’, sweeps down a plane and can detect various objects inside. Romanian company MB Telecom has revealed the Roboscan 2M Aeria. It uses a cone of radiation to sweep across planes and look inside. The device is accurate enough to find a filament in a light bulb. But the radiation it emits is not safe for passengers yet.

Resorts on its Black Sea coast offer best value in terms of a meal out, buying a cup of coffee and essentials such as sun cream and a cold drink, according to a study.

Chinese designers have developed a washing machine so cyclists can clean clothes while exercising. The Bike Washing Machine contains a drum in its front wheel which spins as the user pedals. When ridden, the pedalling motion causes the drum to rotate, churning your clothes inside like a traditional washer. A generator inside the bike also creates electricity which can be stored for later use. The invention could also find use in remote areas where people do not have access to reliable electricity.
Eloise Parry, 21, died this week after taking a lethal overdose of diet pills. She 'burned up from the inside, after swallowing the highly-toxic substance known as Dinitrophenol, or DNP'After taking the tablets her metabolism began to soar and she started to overheat. Doctors desperately tried to stabilise her, but she died just three hours later. Her mother has issued a stark warning about buying diet pills online.

Police are offering a £20k reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the criminal.

Mary Doyle Keefe, the telephone operator who inspired millions, passed away on Tuesday after a brief illness, her family said. Mary became the poster girl for American women when she shot to fame by posing for Norman Rockwell's iconic painting. Rockwell wanted 'Rosie' to show strength, so he used artistic licence to make her arms, hands and shoulders bigger.
The European Parliament is set to vote on whether alcoholic beverages must include calorie counts on their labels. Under current EU regulations, producers of alcoholic drinks are not obliged to reveal the nutritional value of their products on the label. Winemakers say introducing nutritional labelling would lead to an intolerable rise in production costs, and hit smaller vineyards.

Study by Lancashire's Edge Hill University and the University of South Australia found a direct link between anxiety ahead of taking exams and grades achieved. It said pupils who worry about their exam performance are more likely to do badly than those who are less anxious. Principal at Burlington Danes Academy Michael Ribton says parents should pin their offspring's revision timetable on the fridge.

Paramedics are leaving firemen to deal with 999 calls, healthcare leaders warn. Many firemen have not been trained in basic first aid - yet they are being left to care for seriously ill elderly patients for hours while they wait for an ambulance. Fire Brigades Union say practice is irresponsible and dangerous but is becoming increasingly common because ambulance service is so overstretched.

His surgery has been unable to attract a replacement and is currently functioning with a skeleton service. Health bosses responsible for North Wales said difficulties recruiting GPs is a national issue.
A second eruption from the Calbuco volcano in southern Chile has covered nearby towns and villages in a thick layer of ash. The first eruption in over four decades sent vast clouds of dust more than six miles into the air, creating an incredible display of lightning and lava against the night sky. Another unexpected eruption in the Los Lagos Region today heightened fears of local waters becoming contaminated, residents developing severe breathing problems and more flights being grounded.

Despite the fact the Aerostar plane travels at speed, its descent towards the landing strip appears normal until the video maker makes a startling observation. He states that the landing gear has not been deployed and at that very moment the plane touches down with a bump and scratches along the tarmac. The plane's propellers can be heard ricocheting off the ground as the wings bounce up and down from the impact.

Michael Hanline, 69, was convicted of murder for the fatal shooting of truck driver J.T. McGarr in 1980. But more than three decades after he was incarcerated, it emerged that crucial DNA analysis and investigative reports were withheld from his original trial. The new evidence proved that Hanline was innocent and the longest-serving wrongfully imprisoned inmate in Californian history was finally released last November.

The directives are set to be brought into national law in non-EU Norway, which has caused vets to see red.

Study claims these 'taxibots' could cut the number of cars needed to perform the same number of journeys per day by 90 per cent. The finding comes amid reports that companies such as Google and Uber are working on technology to develop driverless taxis. The study, by Paris-based Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, used data from Lisbon in Portugal. It simulated how such self-driving, communal cabs would affect traffic.

Image shows a giant distant cluster of about 3,000 stars called Westerlund 2 inside a stellar 'breeding ground' called Gum 29, 20,000 light-years from Earth. Massive young stars can be seen feeding a nearby region with the fuel it needs to form new stars. Hubble captured the image using its Wide Field Camera 3, which pierced through the dusty veil of dust and gas.

Bikram yoga involves 26 poses performed in a room heated to 40°C (105°F), with 40 per cent humidity. Scientists at the University of Wisconsin-La Crosse have warned the practise can raise a person's body temperature and heart rate to dangerous levels. A typical 90-minute class is reduced to just an hour to reduce risks.

Astronomers believe the light in the sky that triggered the conversion of Paul the Apostle may have actually been a falling meteor 2,000 years ago. They say descriptions of Paul's experience - in which he was blinded for three days after seeing a bright light - match accounts of the fireball that streaked across the sky above Chelyabinsk in Russia in 2013.

Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the death of Eric Harris, 44, on April 2. The reserve deputy claims he mistakenly pulled out his gun instead of his Taser and shot dead the man as he fled the scene of an undercover operation. In 2009, the Tulsa Sheriff's Office concluded after an internal investigation that Bates had received special treatment during training and while working as a reserve deputy.
South Yorkshire Police missed 'intelligence and investigative opportunities' to tackle child sex exploitation in Rotherham, a report has found. At least 1,400 children were abused in the town over 16 years, an inquiry by the National Crime Agency (NCA) concluded. The police force did not use 'alternative strategies' to protect victims or gather evidence, and failed to work effectively with local licencing and community safety officers.

The Lyrid meteor shower peaked overnight with between ten and 20 an hour. The Lyrids are so-called because they occur in the constellation Lyra and are visible around the world but best seen from Europe.

Candlestick Park, which was completed in 1960, has been torn down to make way for houses, a hotel and a shopping center. The San Francisco Giants and San Francisco 49ers were the last teams to play at Candlestick, with the Giants leaving at the end of the 1999 season, and the 49ers after 2013. Joe Montana, Jerry Rice, Steve Young, Ronnie Lott, and Terrell Owens were just a few of the other esteemed 49ers to play there.

These include changing catheter and colostomy bags, feeding through a tube and administering morphine. Worrying conclusions come in a survey of 1,000 workers employed by councils and private firms by trade union Unison.

Ilia de Mana is a 15-acre outcrop shaped like a tortoise shell in the bay of Angra dos Reis, between Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, Brazil. The island has a main residence and four chalets over crystal clear water, with air-conditioned rooms to beat the Brazilian heat. The main residence has a dining room, fully-fitted kitchen and two living rooms for entertaining; every building is solar powered.

Bruce Cook has been warned by police that he may face serious charges if he doesn't take down his 'offensive' hay bale structure out in front of his property at Lake Charm, northwest of Victoria. The 59-year-old put up his'realistic' artwork on Good Friday just for 'a bit of fun'He says many passersby have enjoyed his sculpture and even stopped to take photos. The farmer says he will be adding fairy lights to the structure tonight and plans to add an extra two calves to complete the sculpture.
Security researchers have discovered a way to intercept a person's fingerprints on a Samsung Galaxy S5 running Android 4.4 and older. A hacker can access the kernel, or core, of the Android operating system. Once inside they can monitor all data sent to and from the phone, as well as data recorded by the handset's built-in sensors, including the fingerprint scanner. When a fingerprint is scanned it is encrypted and separated from the rest of the device in a secure folder. Hackers typically can't access this encrypted file, but the flaw allows them to collect scans from the sensor before being encrypted.
The animal became stuck in the quagmire during the night and was lying on her side in a state of desperation when locals came across her and raised the alarm. It took the combined efforts of more than 20 people to haul the five-ton animal from the mud. Rescuers quickly administered anti-infection and anti-shock drugs to stabilise the elephant's condition.
One of the Hillsborough samaritans has come forward after an appeal was launched to identify fans who tended to the wounded as they lay dying on the pitch at the 1989 disaster. Photographs show the men and women rushing towards those crushed in the tragedy were released, with investigators urging anyone who recognises them to come forward. They form part of an ongoing Home Office inquiry aiming to establish whether any individual or organisation was to blame for the disaster which claimed the lives of 96 Liverpool fans.

Researchers at the University of Bath and Yale University created the invention. It uses a newly designed catalyst to split water in an electrolyser and create clean and storable hydrogen fuel. Hydrogen-fuel is appealing for use in cars like the Vauxhall Zafira minivan, but producing hydrogen requires huge amounts of energy. With the new breakthrough, it could be possible to make it more easily.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene, like Hollywood star Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. Researchers in Canada analysed 676 breast cancer patients who had one of the mutated genes. Nearly half (345) underwent oophorectomy after their diagnosis.
Christian Tyrrell, 22, was arrested Wednesday on capital murder charges in connection to the March 19 death of 2-year-old Adrian Langlais. Adrian's adoptive grandparents John Winkler and Laura Martinez considered themselves Adrian's grandparents, even though they weren't blood related to the little boy. The couple said they started noticing bruises and other injuries on Adrian last fall, when his girlfriend started dating Tyrrell. Eventually, they reported Adrian's injuries to Child Protective Services, but the agency closed the investigation in February, ruling out abuse from Adrian's parents. A little over a month later, Adrian was dead in the hospital from head trauma.

Facebook has launched a new app called Hello designed to give you more control over who can call you and how their details appear - even if their number isn't stored in your contacts book. It pulls in any publicly-shared data from a user's Facebook profile and lets you easily block unwanted callers. The free app is currently in testing and is only available on Android devices in the US. It is expected to roll out to other regions and devices if testing is successful.
A Russian scientist says the distant ancestor of humans had tentacles. They lived more than 540 million years ago and used them for food. It's likely they also had a complex nervous system like we do today. Dr Elena Temereva came to her conclusion by studying the 'living fossil' Lingula anatina, an ancient brachiopod found all over the world.

It says that amateur astronomers could help with its 'unprecedented' search for ET by accessing research data online. The initiative, dubbed Nexus for Exoplanet System Science (Nexss), will include scientists from 10 universities.

Cleveland's Variety Theater was home to one of the earliest single screen cinemas in Cleveland, Ohio, before becoming an iconic music venue. The 20,000 sq ft main stage hosted the likes of Metallica, the Dead Kennedy's and R.E.M. before Motorhead's fatal performance on December 2 1984. The venue was closed after the ceiling cracked and pieces of plaster began to fall on the audience during a 1984 gig.

The pilot scheme is launching in Munich next month and Amazon has teamed up with Audi and DHL to run the initiative. Prime customers selected for the trial will be given the option to pinpoint the location of their car on a map in delivery options. Once ordered, a DHL delivery driver will receive a temporary digital access code. This code gives the driver keyless access to the boot of the car up until the delivery is made. As soon as the boot is closed the vehicle is locked automatically, and the code is revoked.

There were 3,700 women who served in the Nazi death camps during the Second World War. Only three have been investigated by prosecutors in Germany for their roles as accomplices to mass murder. Charlotte S, now 94, was a guard at the notorious women's concentration camp of Ravensbrueck, in northern Germany. Gisela S, a 'hard-faced' woman who worked in the women's camp of Bergen-Belsen was discharged from the service in 1943 when she fell pregnant.
GetUp's new website, The Gender Price Gap, has exposed nine everyday items that cost more for women. This is despite the products being identical in almost every way except whether they are targeted towards women or men. Bonds has been identified as one of the main culprits, advertising a button-up shirt, that comes in both'summer blue' and 'blue denim' colour options, on their Australian website for $59.95. Other examples show increases from as little as 11c or even 1c for items marketed towards females.

Foreskin facials, also known as HydraFacials, are the latest unconventional beauty treatment to be hitting salons in New York. Dubbed a HydraFacial, the treatment costs around $150 (£100) and uses stem cell from an infant's foreskin. The 30-minute treatment involves a cleansing process using salicylic-and-glycolic-acid peel, an extraction, a mask packed with hydrating hyaluronic acid and a serum with foreskin extracts.
Ali Maffucci, 28, lost 11 kg (almost two stone) in three months through replacing pasta, bread and rice with spirazlied vegetables. The spiralizer is a razor-sharp cutting device that creates thin ribbons of fruits and vegetables. Originally a Japanese invention, it allows people to create low-calorie, low-carb ‘pasta’, ‘noodles’ and ‘rice’ in less time than it takes to peel a potato.

Archaeologists have discovered evidence that Neanderthals regularly inhabited the Cave of Llenes, near Senterada in Catalonia, around 200,000 years ago. Remains of other canivores including cave bears, hyenas, leopards, wolves and badgers have been found in the cave and were apparently also living there. It is hoped the discoveries will help scientists learn more about Neanderthal behaviour.

Moore escaped from police custody three times during the 1970s and eventually settled into a quiet life, living in Kentucky since at least 2009. His health is poor from a stroke late last year and he has difficulty speaking. When Franklin County Sheriff Pat Melton showed up at Moore's house to make the 'arrest,' Moore was in a hospital bed and broke down in tears.

One in seven U.S. residents will be an immigrant by 2023, the report from the Center for Immigration Studies said. That number could rise to one in five by 2060, when immigrant population reaches 78 million. President Barack Obama is trying to use executive powers to expand immigration policies, which could exempt about 5million undocumented immigrants from deportation.

Scientists in The Netherlands were using the Lofar radio telescope. They found it could measure changes in lightning caused by cosmic rays. A storm can have hundreds of millions of volts over multiple kilometres. The method could provide a novel way to understand thunderclouds.
Andrew Steele had pleaded not guilty by reason of mental disease to two counts of first-degree intentional homicide in the August 22 shooting deaths of his wife, Ashlee Steele, and her sister, 38-year-old Kacee Tollefsbol. Defense attorneys argued that Lou Gehrig's disease had damaged Steele's brain, making him not criminally responsible for the deaths. A jury deliberated for about 10 hours until all but two of the 12 agreed the verdict early on Thursday.
Sales of prosecco have overtaken champagne for the first time, according to industry figures. Prosecco has long been seen as the second choice to champagne in the UK. Last year UK sales overtook those of champagne for first time - £181.8 million compared to £141.3 million.
Andrew Hutchinson raped two patients while they were under general anaesthetic and assaulted others at John Radcliffe Hospital Oxford where he worked in the A&E department between 2011 and 2013. The 29-year-old was convicted of 23 separate charges last month including making indecent images of children, outraging public decency and voyeurism. He was taken into custody at Oxford Crown Court and is due to be sentenced next week. It has since emerged that an earlier complaint about the nurse was made to bosses at Oxford University Hospitals Trust.
Identical twins share 100 per cent of their genes, meaning it has been impossible to tell which sibling a sample comes from. But researchers at the University of Huddersfield have created a technique which they claim can distinguish between the genetic fingerprints of identical twins. The technique is based on the concept of DNA methylation - the molecular mechanism that turns various genes on and off.
Sid Ahmed Ghlam, 24, allegedly had armoury of weapons, including Kalashnikovs. He was arrested on Sunday after allegedly murdering Aurelie Chatelain, 33, in Paris suburb of Villejuif. Mr Valls said: 'Numerous attacks had already been foiled - five if you take into account the attack which happily did not take place'He added: 'The threat has never been as high. We have never had to face this kind of terrorism in our history'
Volcano Calbuco, in southern Chile, has erupted for the first time in more than five decades on Wednesday, sending a thick plume of ash and smoke several kilometres into the sky. An estimated 1,500 people were forced to flee the nearby town of Ensenada after the eruption, while several smaller townships were also cleared. The volcano is believed to be among the three most dangerous of Chile's 90 active volcanoes, but was not under any special observation before it erupted.

Carl Bradey lost everything he owned in the blaze, which was started by a candle in his Palmerston North rental property last month. The 25-year-old smashed through a window to rescue the child of a family friend, suffering nerve damage that has left him unable to feel anything in his right arm. He has undergone four major operations, including multiple skin grafts and the removal of a damaged vein. The house has been demolished because there was asbestos found in the property.

The Clinton Foundation and the Clinton Health Access Initiative said they will be refiling multiple annual tax returns and may audit returns extending as far back as 15 years in case there have been other errors.

He had always insisted he and his wife had kissed on the night in question but they had not had sex. The couple were married seven years after meeting at a church choir and had both been widowed.

Man-made quakes jolted once stable regions in eight states, including parts of Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico, Ohio, Oklahoma and Texas. Earthquakes were sometimes caused by fracking, in which large volumes of water, sand and chemicals are pumped into rock formations to free oil or gas.

Greece warned it will go bankrupt next week after failing to stump up enough cash to pay millions of public sector workers and its international debts. Deputy finance minister Dimitras Mardas declared the country had been 'running on empty' since February. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is expected to appeal to German Chancellor Angela Merkel for more aid to avoid going bust and a potential exit from the euro.

But after turning up at her company's address, he discovered it had been closed for years. The pair have sent each other 396 emails in the last 11 months and Mr Malone claims he has spent more than 11,000 Yuan (£1,100), paying for translators to communicate.
Stephanie Scott's mother Anika Stanford is helping police with the murder case against her son, Vincent Stanford. Ms Stanford is believed to have given police information which led them to a road in the Cocoparra National Park, where they discovered Ms Scott's burnt remains on April 10, five days after she went missing. Vincent Stanford, 24, has been charged with the Easter Sunday murder of Ms Scott, who disappeared the weekend before her wedding to fiance Aaron Leeson-Woolley. He will next appear in Griffith Court by video link on June 4. The family have lived in Leeton for just 14 months, and previously lived in the Netherlands.

She told police that he had been watching her for years when she was undressing and when he believed she was asleep.

The 46-year-old teaching assistant believes her cancer developed from getting badly burned on holiday in Lanzarote when she was 15 - where she also bought cheap sunglasses without proper UV protection. Debbie is now cancer free but has to stay out of the sun, and wears a patch over her eye.

Antoni van Leeuwenhoek used his body as a guinea pig in an experiment. He took three lice, nestled them among the hairs of his calf, rolled up a tight stocking so that the insects were bound to his leg and did not bathe for six days.

Curiously absent from the final vote was Texas Senator Ted Cruz - a key opponent of Lynch's nomination. He was the only member of the Senate who did not cast a vote. A copy of a Cruz for President invitation later began flying around Twitter that showed the GOP presidential candidate had skipped town early to make an appearance at a fundraiser at the home of former Texas Rangers owner Tom Hicks.

George, a Chicago native, died Friday at age 78, of kidney cancer. He was to be buried Thursday in his family's plot at All Saints Cemetery in nearby Des Plaines.

The film stars Sandler, Taylor Lautner, Nick Nolte and Steve Buscemi and is a spoof of The Magnificent Seven that stars and was written by Sandler. Navajo Nation tribal member Loren Anthony said the film was offensive towards Native American women. Anthony said that though the film is about the Apache, extras were dressed more like Comanche (traditional dress on right), with braids and chokers.

Paul claims he was getting ready to drive Brock to school when he left the sleeping boy in the car to run inside and grab something. While inside, someone stole the car, and he and his wife immediately called officers. When they arrived on the scene they said Suzanne refused to let them in, and that they thought appeared to be blood inside the home.

Social media users were left scratching their heads over some of the manipulated snaps being shared during New South Wales’ worst storm in a decade. While there were many genuine dramatic photos to emerge from the devastating storm, such as torn up roads and floating houses, not all of them were quite what they seemed. A family-sized trampoline believed to have blown into the sky in the cyclone-strength gusts in NSW was actually a victim of Hurricane Sandy in Milford, Connecticut, USA. The more unbelievable Photoshop jobs included a photo of Noah’s Ark majestically cruising into Sydney Harbour amidst a grey stormy backdrop and a Bondi house with sand pouring through its doors.

Surgeons sawed through his jawbone and removed part of the tongue to get to the tumour. They then replaced the lost tissue with muscle from Mr Billing's arm - which still has hairs on it. He is now preparing to run the London Marathon to raise money for Cancer Research.

German banking giant Deutsche Bank will pay $2.5 billion in fines for its role in a vast multi-year conspiracy to rig LIBOR interest rates, US and British authorities said on Thursday. Case centers on charges that Deutsche Bank derivatives traders manipulated the London InterBank Offered Rate, used to peg millions of interest rate-sensitive contracts and loans around the world.

Gang of eight dug a 50m underground tunnel in an attempt to steal treasures inside a 1,400-year-old temple. They began their plan by renting a restaurant across the road from Guanghui Temple in Zhengdin County, North China at the start of February. While serving snacks to the public at the front of the building, a team on the inside was hard at work with shovels, ladders, and power drills. The gang was just 20 metres away from breaching the Hua Pagoda when they were caught. Five men were arrested following a tip-off, but three are still on the run.

Mr Harding served as an aircraft handler on the warship many decades before his young friends were born. World leaders were joined by Princes Charles and Harry on the Royal Navy's flagship HMS Bulwark in Turkey's Dardanelles straits to mark the centenary of the catastrophic landings. An estimated 1,000 Allied soldiers died on the first day of the disastrous invasion until January 1916, when after huge losses on both sides, the Allies successfully fooled the Turkish forces. Historian Stephen Chambers has collected more than 100 rare photographs, many taken by the troops themselves, including poignant images of soldiers from their preparation for the first landings right up until the evacuation.

China's building activity has infuriated neighbouring countries and the United States. President Barack Obama accused China of using its military might to reclaim territory.

Living near a congested road can increase the chance of developing dementia. Exposure to small, sooty particles, mostly caused by traffic fumes and factory emissions, alters the structure of the brain.
Switzerland is the world's happiest nation thanks to healthy GDP figures, strong social bonds and an increasing life expectancy. The list is dominated by European nations, particularly those in Scandinavia, and measures a country's population by factors contributing to its citizens' contentment, rather than wealth. Britons are happier now than they were two years ago, the study found, but still ranks in at a relatively lowly 21st place. Despite often mocking its northern neighbour as an inferior nation, the United States is a full 10 places below Canada, ranking at 10th and fifth respectively.

He posted photos of the silver medal to an online fossicking forum, which led him to Sydney man Stephen Norton. Mr Manzie says it made his year to be able to return the medal to a living relative ahead of ANZAC Day Centenary this weekend.

Anthony Trollope introduced post boxes to the UK in 1852 after seeing them in France. The first boxes were erected in Jersey as a trial before appearing across mainland Britain. They were initially painted green, to blend in with the landscape, but that was later changed to red.

So he instructed workers at the farm to varnish the claws of each fluffy owlet using nail polish. The first born Tawny owl is given orange talons, the second hatched has theirs painted purple and for the third born, pink.

The Martingale Betting Strategy of doubling up originated in France and is used with success by punters on ANZAC Day throughout Australia. Punters simply bet a stake to win an amount of money, if they fail to win with the first bet they increase their stake to recover their losses plus win the initial targeted win amount on the second bet. Two Up is one of Australia's longest lasting traditions, it dates back to Australia's goldfields.

Her father, Tom Parks, said she had abused alcohol and prescription pills before moving on to heroin. He pleaded with other families to'stay right on top' of loved ones with addictions.

Vladmir Lenin may have been dead for 90 years, but his corpse looks better than the day he passed. This is the claim made by his embalmers, who have developed experimental techniques to maintain the look and feel of the communist revolutionary's body. The gruesome job is the responsibility of a team known as the 'Mausoleum group' which, at its peak, involved 200 scientists working in a lab dedicated to the former leader's corpse.

Anzac Day falls on a Saturday this year, meaning all states but WA will miss out on holiday on Monday. The agreement was designed to provide uniformity of public holidays across the nation. If Easter, Christmas, Australia Day, the Queen's Birthday or Labour Day fall on a weekend, a holiday is granted on a weekday. Bosses in some states have been warned to expect a rise in employees calling in sick this Monday.

A supervolcano in Yellowstone National Park releases around 45,000 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide each day. A magma chamber beneath the surface is not considered large enough to produce these levels. Now, geophysicists have discovered an enormous secondary chamber deeper underground that's so large its partly-molten rock could fill the Grand Canyon 11 times over.

Brain scans on professional comedians revealed differences in the way the brains of these'super speakers' work while talking. Super speakers showed less activity in a key area of the brain involved articulating and comprehending speech. This suggests that this group were putting less effort into the basic mechanics of speech, allowing them to devote more resources to what they were going to say next.

Parker thought a rock had struck him in the face but after going to Memorial Hospital a scan revealed it was a three-and-a-half-inch metal fence wire. Dr Timothy Haffey removed the wire with a simple sinus surgery which took 20 minutes and entailed making an incision on Parker's upper lip.

Navinder Sarao lived in his parents' semi-detached home in Hounslow, west London. It is closer to an internet server used by major financial exchanges, giving him a nanosecond advantage. Thousands of high-frequency trades could be processed faster than those from dealers in Central London. Sarao allegedly made £550,000 in five minutes on the day of the 'Flash Crash', the biggest one-day collapse in Wall Street history. He is accused of using computer programs to create'spoof' transactions on Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

Instead, consumers willing to shell out between $549 to $17,000 - for the gold edition - have to pre-order the watches online and wait for their arrival until June. New study by Consumer Reports in the US has found traces of harmful bacteria in prawns. They tested 342 packages of frozen shrimp - 284 raw and 58 cooked samples - from chain supermarkets and natural food stores in 27 cities across the US. The majority of the shrimp sold on supermarket shelves arrive there after starting life on vast prawn farms in south east Asia.

She had been promoted to manager at the nursery by its owner who knew her and trusted her. Much of the money was taken from a cash box on the wall that parents left their fees in. Nursery owner Lynda Quigley received £22,643 via bank transfer on April 22. Crossland was sentenced to a 12-month community order and 180 hours unpaid work.

Fifteen people have died since records began in 1924 and dozens are injured each year in the annual event, known as the encierro.

Australian researchers have tested their drone running companion. Called Joggobot it is designed to float in front of jogger when they run. Technology could allow it to track the speed and direction of the runner. And it could be used for other sports like cycling and rowing.
Aussie the dog saved his owners Kai, seven, and Sophie, 10, from being electrocuted in a puddle near their home at Caves Beach, near Lake Macquarie, on Wednesday. The family home had lost power so on Wednesday the children's mother Natalie Crane-Hayes decided to take Kai, Sophie and Aussie for a walk in a nearby park. The park was full of large puddles and they didn't know it at the time, but the wild weather had caused a power line to fall down into one of them meaning all the water in the park was live with electrical current. Five-month-old Aussie was walking just ahead of the kids and when he stepped into the first puddle he was killed instantly. 'Aussie's our hero, he saved their lives,' their grandmother Deanna Addicoat said.

Seconds later they throw themselves into the flames while a Hindu priest uses oil to stoke the blaze as he chants religious hymns. The annual fire festival lasts for 11 days and sees dozens of participants dangle over the flames.

The Statue of Liberty was evacuated Friday afternoon in the wake of a bomb threat, which was ultimately found to be a hoax. Some 2,700 tourists were rushed off Liverty Island by boat operators just after midday Friday after a 911 caller said he was 'going to blow up' the landmark. Police sniffer dogs then seized on a locker on the island, which they thought contained something suspicious. The NYPD bomb squad was scrambled, but a full search of the island finally failed to find anything explosive.

The records are among the 12 million WWI historical documents available in Australia. Nicole Kidman's great-grandfather, Edward Glenny, worked as a private in the military running the wireless communications during WWI. Geoffrey Rush's great uncle, James Thomas Rush, served in the 15th Infantry Battalion of the Australian Army. He was wounded in France in September 1918. Naomi Watt's grandfather, Baden Charles Rush, was 18 when he enlisted for WWI. He served in Corps B of the Flying Corps but was never sent overseas to fight.

Genetic analysis of two woolly mammoth remains show that their population became so small that they had become chronically inbred. The last of the woolly mammoths were isolated on an Arctic island for around 5,000 years, forcing them to inbreed as their population dwindled until disappering 4,500 years ago. The study has also raised the prospect of bringing the giant mammal back to life using cloning techniques with modern elephants.

Temperatures set to plunge by around ten degrees next week, forecasters predict. It also threatens to cause a wet and miserable time for runners taking part in London Marathon.

Measuring just 15ft by 10ft, hut on Mudeford Spit in Christchurch, Dorset, is the same price as a five-bedroom house in Herefordshire and more than a four-bedroom home in Kingswood, Hull. Owners will also have to shell out between £2,500 and £4,000 a year in ground rent to Christchurch Borough Council for use of the hut which can sleep up to five people. The hut commands spectacular views across Christchurch Bay to the Needles and the Isle of Wight.

Chief executive Clive Schlee revealed he has given his staff the power to hand out a coffee on the house to people they like or fancy. Deni tried three different approaches: nonchalant, sad and friendly.
Tibetan Mastiffs are so unpopular in China they are being sent to slaughterhouses - and their meat put into cheap hotpots. The dogs' dramatic decline in fortune is being partly blamed on the Chinese government's wide-reaching anti-corruption crackdown.
The majority of the world’s volcanoes are found deep underwater and now scientists have been able to record one of these eruptions as it happens to discover the sound it makes - and they are surprisingly quiet for such a violent event. Rather than the explosive roar emitted by their cousins on land, underwater volcanoes give off a muted thrum instead. The research could allow scientists to monitor undersea volcanoes far more effectively than they have before.

His manager, Dino May, said there were no signs of trouble prior to him taking his own life. Sawyer appeared in 139 episodes of the popular US sitcom and also took small parts in television shows Even Stevens and Frank McKlusky C.I.

The middle school student was sitting in the otherwise empty carriage when the woman boarded the CTA train in Oak Park on Monday at 3pm.

She could face up to 45 years in prison when she is sentenced next month. Altice's attorney, Ed Brass, said his client wanted to resolve a case to avoid risking an uncertain outcome at trial.
Engineers have developed a Human Powered Vehicle (HPV)It will attempt to beat the women's arm-powered speed record in Nevada in September. It will be powered by paracyclist Liz McTernan and will need to travel in excess of 21.39 miles per hour (34.42 km/h) over a 656ft (200-metre) stretch of tarmac. The current benchmark is held by Tracy Miller who broke the record on 13 May 1995 on a bike called Chairiot.

All three victims were gunned down at their homes in daylight attacks: Dunning in 2003, Kirby in 2013 and Lodato last year. At court on Thursday, prosecutor Bryan Porter argued Severance should face just one trial as his writings linked the three murders. Judge Jane Marum Roush also decided at the hearing that Severance's trial should be moved from Alexandria to Fairfax County.
